text:
I can't get enough of this soup!  I tweaked it by leaving out the bacon and using kale instead of spinach (the famous restaurant uses kale).  I also added 1 teaspoon of fennel as I think that it is crucial to the flavor of the soup.  My Italian sausage was hot enough without the added red pepper, also.  Still, I think this recipe is pretty forgiving and you can add or subtract to your taste.  This was just what I was looking for to start me on my way to my new favorite soup.  I also loved how quickly everything cooked.

text:
This is a great soup.  Use Kale in place of the spinach and voila, you have the original recipe!  HELPFUL HINTS:  To avoid orange soup, rinse your sausage in very HOT water; use 5 potatoes sliced thick and 2 potatoes sliced thin.  The variation in the potato size allows the thinly sliced potatoes to cook down and thicken the broth; a mix of hot and mild sausage gives the soup more "zip", and last, use low sodium chicken broth.   Serve with hot crusty bread for a great meal.

text:
This is very similar to a recipe that I make.  I use hot sausage instead of mild, no hot pepper flakes, only 2-4 russett potatoes (depending on the size)sliced thin and they hold their shape and do not come out mushy and kale.  You can substitute cauliflower for the potatoes for a lower carb diet and it is just as delicious.  Definately just crumble the bacon instead of cutting into pieces.  This is a crowd pleaser and my family loves it when I make this recipe!

INeedAllTheHelpICanGet

city:

country:
None
text:
Excellent!! I've tried other recipes that were supposed to be "exactly like" the restaurant version... but none have ever come out the way I expected - until now.  However, I did use kale, not spinach, and I added fennel seed as someone else suggested (thank you). I chopped the fennel seed (about 1.5 tsp) and added it in with the chicken broth (I forgot to add it while cooking the sausage).  I added two big handfuls of chopped kale after adding the cream. Also, I used one 48oz can of chicken broth, and one 14oz can of chicken broth with roasted garlic (I still used the garlic called for in the recipe - and probably a little extra since we like garlic).  If I would change anything next time, I would use less sausage (I used 18oz).  I would only use 10-12oz next time (at the most).  Also, I used 3 very large potatoes (not the huge bakers, but very large), but I don't think it was enough. We like a lot of potatoes.  Also, I wouldn't slice them too thin. Chop them large enough to get a little beat up while stirring/cooking but still remain chunky. I sliced mine about 1/2" thick, then cut the slices in half, but I wish I had just used bigger chunks instead of slices.  They didn't take 20 minutes to cook this way so watch your potatoes closely, they may be mushy if you let them cook for the full 20 minutes. (Mine were good at 15 min). One last note - I don't think you really need a full cup of cream. You could survive with 3/4 c. & not miss the fat or any of the taste.

text:
Great recipe! I had to tweak it a little, but that's ok, I always tweak whatever recipe I look at... a full pound of sausage was a bit much for me so I used a half a pound, and make sure you blot all the grease from the sausage or it will float to the top. Instead of spinach I used kale, it's a heartier green and doesn't wilt in the soup, the texture stays firm for a long time. Delicious!!

text:
Definitely oh-so-good. I followed the recipe exact, only adding a tsp. of crushed fennel as another reviewer recommended. My family was not a fan but I am for sure. I'm really glad I didn't double it because it makes quite a bit for one person. Make sure you invite your besties over to share if you make this. Quite simple and not intimidating like I originally thought it would be. NOTE: If you have kids, you might want to cut back on the red pepper flakes. It's got a bit of a kick, which could be a bit much for little mouths. Also, my potatoes were done at 12 minutes.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
There is a reason this is the highest rated and most reviewed Zuppa Toscana recipe on the site...not only does the list of ingredients capture the essence of what you need to make this simple but great soup, but the sum total of all the raters' comments and suggestions help to guide one to creating their own masterpiece.  As I always do, I first read the original recipe and creator's directions carefully to determine if the dish is something that generally suits my taste and style of cooking.  Then, I carefully read a great many of the reviews of the recipe in attempt to determine if others have indeed found ways to improve the dish.  I would say that 50% of the time or more I find great value in the trial and error suggestions reviewers have so graciously offered to assist all of us in our ever-evolving quest to make things a little better.  At any rate, this dish is such a great example of all those attributes.  For me personally, I benefitted greatly from the many wonderful and thoughtful suggestions and modifications other reviewers had made.  The modifications I made were as follows:  1) I used 3 large red russet potatoes and the florets from one whole head of cauliflower, 2) I used thick-cut bacon which I fried, then set aside to drain and crumbled versus leaving in 1/2 inch strips 3) I used about 1/2 tsp red pepper flakes versus 1 1/4, 3) I used half-and-half versus heavy cream, 4) lastly, and most importantly, I used kale instead of spinach.  Outstanding Zuppa!

text:
My favorite soup by far! Try the recipe as is first!  Wonderful to double or quadruple recipe for freezing. To freeze: After step 2, add the sausage & red pepper back in with bacon, onion & garlic. Mix & let cool, put meat mixture into freezer bag. Thaw when ready to use. Use chicken soup base to make broth & heat like step 3 only waiting to put the meat mixture back in after the potatoes have cooked. Reduce heat & continue with heavy cream & spinach. Enjoy!! Thank-You souporsweets!!!

text:
Suggestions -  ** If you plan to freeze, hold off on the cream, instead add after thawing.   ** Blot the sausage really well, otherwise soup will be greasy.  You do want to saute the onion in the bacon drippings as indicated though. ** Kale would give a snappier and more peppery flavor than spinach.   ** As a better contrast between savory and spicy, use spicy sausage and omit pepper flakes.

text:
This soup is wonderful!  During the unfortunate times that I am dragged kicking and screaming to the odious faux Italian chain to which so many of the reviews here refer, this is the ONLY thing that I will eat.  It's actually quite tasty.  The best part about making this soup at home is serving it with crusty bread rather than the oil & salt saturated dough they call breadsticks.  I went ahead and used the spinach the first time, but will use kale in the future.  I drained and rinsed the sausage, used red new potatoes, and substituted fat free half & half for the heavy cream.  Great rainy day meal, especially with some red wine.

text:
EXCELLENT!!!  I have found another soup to add to my rotation - and that is a hard spot to fill!  The only things I did different was I used chicken stock in place of broth (more flavor), only 2 large potatoes, cubed (left skin on), 2 cups of kale (washed, dried & chopped) in place of the spinach and added slightly more bacon - more like half a pound (7-8 slices).  I had link mild italian sausage so I just had to slice off the casing and crumble myself.  not a big deal. I also probably added slightly more red pepper to the soup - plus salt and ground pepper to taste at the end - so yummy. When I added the cream and kale at the end, I let it simmer for around 4 minutes.  This was so perfect, easy, hubby raved, and i look forward to making it again!

text:
WOW!  This is quite possibly the best tasting soup I've ever made.  This may even be the best tasting soup I've ever had, period.  Delicious, absolutely delicious.  Tasted just like the soup at "the restaurant chain".  I followed this to a tee except I did as the others suggested and used kale instead of spinach.  "The restaurant chain" also uses kale, so I thought it was a much needed change.  Other than that, I followed the recipe and it turned out perfectly.  I used red potatoes, left the skins on and cut the slices in half.  Next time I may cut down on the red pepper flakes (maybe 1 tsp. instead of 1 1/4) because it was a bit too spicy for the kids (though I thought it was perfect).  Perfect with a little fresh grated Parmesan on top and some warm, crusty bread.  Delicious and filling, definitely a meal!  Thank yo so much for this recipe!

Tuesday Nite.....Kroger's was out of Kale, had just used my supply for sauteed side dish on Sunday.  No biggie.  Used spinach.  This is similar to another soup I make that has pinto beans in it.  I cooked according to recipe....Hubby and son loved it.  It's all gone! Now, here is for the sticker shock for all you Zuppa Toscana purists.  I am, as you know, a true Southern choc-o-la-te lady (Dora the Explorer taught me how to say it like that!!!)So, don't be mad....but I ate mine with.....wait for it......cornbread!!!! I know I know.  It's an Italian soup!  But, that broth just begged me for a chunk of cornbread.  My son doesn't eat it so he had good ole fashioned (frozen brand) garlic sticks. Oh my, it was truly delicious though.  Comfort food for my soul!

text:
this soup is AMAZING. follow the recipe to a T, and you will have a very delicious soup. Whenever I make this soup, I always intend to save some, to freeze and pull out on those nights when you don't feel like cooking ... but there is NEVER ANY LEFT, even if I double the recipe. I have made this soup as written many times, but I usually add more bacon (we love bacon).. I use half of a 'regular package' of bacon, cut into chunks. I brown my sausage in the bacon drippings, and then blot the sausage and bacon with paper towel (try to get as much of the grease off as possible so it dosn't linger in the soup). I sautee the onion, garlic and potatoes before adding them to the pot. I try to use homemade chicken broth if I have some, and I usually add 'bunches' of thyme to the broth, stems and all. the thyme leaves cook off the stems, and before the soup is done I pull the stems out. If I use spicy sausage, I leave the crushed red pepper out.. and if I use mild italian I sometimes add fresh diced red pepper instead of the red pep flakes. I use kale, and whipping cream. a family favorite over here  :)))
Review:

country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe, and very easy! I actually cook the onions and garlic a little first to soften, add the sausage (without casings) and cook, then drain the grease. Then I add everything else to the same big pot, (except bacon which I don't really care for.) I def. recommend kale over spinach, and you can use skim milk instead of cream, plus a little corn or potato starch or instant potato flakes to thicken it and it's just as good and a bit better for you! I have worked at that famous Italian restaurant for a long time... and this recipe is exactly what you need to make this soup at home. It's even better if you let it sit overnight. Sprinkle some parmesan or romano cheese on top and it's perfection!

text:
I have been making this soup for a couple of years, it's one of my favorites!  The changes I make are using half and half instead of heavy cream, pancetta instead of bacon and cubed potatoes instead of thinly sliced. Also, instead of adding the spinach or kale (both are good) directly to the soup, I rough chop it and place it in the bottom of the soup bowls and ladle hot soup over it.  With just two of us, we eat this for several meals and the fresh greens each day make it taste just made.

I just finished up my last bowl of this soup, and it was so good! I didn't follow the recipe exactly, but pretty much most of it. I accidentally bought sweet turkey sausage, and it still tasted really good (I did add the pepper flakes to make it spicier). I also didn't have 5 cans of chicken broth, but I had enough for 48 oz and it was a perfect amount for me. I added 1 teaspoon of fennel and 1/4 bunch kale per other reviewers suggestions-made this soup amazing. I had jumbo russet potatoes, so I only added 2 (washed and peeled) and that was PLENTY...so check the size of your potatoes beforehand. My husband loved this, he was impressed :) Thank you!

userID:
1854140
Display Name:
Nikkohli
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
60
favoritesCount:
491
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was SO excited to make this soup because I love the Olive Garden version. This was nothing like it. I followed the directions exactly-only subbing kale for spinach and adding more potatoes (8) and sausage (1.5lbs) because we like a chunky soup and I read reviews that this was thin. I sliced 2 of the potatoes thinner so they could cook down to thicken the soup and the rest I sliced medium thickness so they wouldn't cook away.  When the soup was ready I tasted it and it was SO thin and bland. It tasted like red pepper flake-flavored, watery chicken broth. I took about 2 ladle fulls of the soup out (sausage, taters and all)and blended a quick roux with some cornstarch and an extra large baked potato. It was still SO thin and tasteless--the chicken broth flavor was really overwhelming.   Finally to salvage dinner (and a lot of leftovers) I added about 2 cups of potato flakes. I added them slowly and whisked to avoid clumping. This thickened the soup up beautifully and really cut the chicken broth taste. I bet after cooling overnight, the leftovers will soak up a lot of the broth so I suggest starting with just one cup of potato flakes so the flavor and thickness doesn't overwhelm and add more the next day if needed.   I gave this a 2 stars because as directed it was pretty much unedible. Adding the potato flakes made it 3.5 (had a bit more "mashed potato flavor" than OG's soup) but I bet with some playing around with the potato flakes this could be a 4-5 star recipe.

userID:
1032812
Display Name:
Michelle Roth-Kiva
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2689406.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh. My. Gossssshhhhh!!!!! This was soooooo good!!! Both my hubs and I REALLY enjoyed this! This is a SPOT in copycat of the "real deal." :) Although pretty much perfect as is, I made a few changes (I know, I know...). To help eliminate some of the greasiness others have warned about, I browned (HOT) sausage links in a bit of garlic infused EVOO, gently blotted them with paper towels after they had cooled and then roughly chopped them into bite-sized pieces. Because of this change, I omitted the pepper flakes altogether. I ended up using four good sized Russett potatoes and am glad I did. Six would have been FAR too many! Since the recipe submitter doesn't specify the size of potato to use, it's imperative to trust your gut on this one.... Six SMALL potatoes might be fine, but cut back if they are any larger than that. My final change was to substitute chopped kale for spinach (to more closely mimic the chain's soup). With these changes, this was one darn good soup! Garlic breadsticks rounded out our delicious meal. It will be a VERY long time before I make another visit to the "Garden" to satisfy my soup craving haha! Thanks SO much for sharing your secret recipe with the AR community, souporsweets! :-)

text:
This recipe is excellent as is! After making it the first time, I now use paper towels to soak up as much grease off the sausage and bacon after cooking. Depending on my mood, I'll use less sausage since the original does have a lot of meat in it. Sometimes I use reduced fat condensed milk instead of cream, and sometimes I use kale or swiss chard instead of spinach. That's the great thing about soup; you can alter it to your preferences or what's on hand. This one's a keeper!

text:
Very good soup, however, I would reduce the amount of broth. All of the delicious flavors of the soup are watered down by too much broth. I would recommend more like a 48 oz. carton of chicken broth. Also, use low sodium broth and add salt to taste. I made this slightly healthier by using Italian seasoned ground turkey instead of sausage and half & half instead of heavy cream. We like a little spice, but not too much, so I only added 1/2 tsp. crushed red pepper. Served it with "Soft Garlic Breadsticks" from this site and it was a nice, warming meal.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1901702.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Mmmmm.  I doubled the bacon and made sure it was really crispy before crumbling into the soup.  I added extra garlic and onion as those are two of my favorite flavors.  I ended up using extra cream (healthy, I know) and tossed about a 1/2 cup of instant mashed potato flakes in at the end which thickened the soup really nicely.  I only used 4 russet potatoes and ended up with a good ratio of potatoes to the creamy soup.  I used hot italian sausage and still added the crushed red pepper flakes (we like it hot).  I am not generally a fan of fennel but wanted to get as close to possible to the OG recipe so I added 1 teaspoon of roughly chopped fennel seed to the sausage when I was browning it…I'm glad I did.  It's definitely in the OG version and I think I would miss it if I hadn't added it.  I tasted the soup toward the end and didn't feel it was salty enough so I used some garlic salt to enhance the flavor…perfect.  Kale all day…no spinach.  We froze the yummy leftovers and have been enjoying this delicious soup for the past week!  Will definitely be making this one again.

text:
Yum, yum, yum!  We absolutely loved this soup.  Based on other reviewers suggestions, I used Kale instead of Spinach and light half and half cream instead of heavy cream.  I lightly sauteed the Kale in the pan I cooked the bacon in (with grease removed; just the remnants in the pan to give the Kale a little flavour).  Used Blue Menu (Zehrs brand) italian sausage, casing removed  (half the fat of regular) and Yukon Gold potatoes.  The taste was out of this world!  My DH kept commenting on how good this soup was--which is a real testament to how good this really was.  Thank you for the recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turned out great! But I made some of the same changes everyone else did- I used kale instead of spinach, spicy italian sausage and omitted the pepper flakes, and used store bought bacon crumbles instead of cooking my own bacon to cut down on the fat. I also used fat free half & half instead of heavy cream, and boullion instead of broth. 
Also, on a side note, do not boil your potatoes for 20 minutes as the recipe states. For thinly sliced potatoes, this is way too long. I boil the broth (with onion, garlic and bacon), add the potatoes then immediately reduce heat to a simmer. About 10 minutes or so is plenty of time on a strong simmer to cook the potatoes through.

text:
Absolutely fantastic! I have made this twice now, both within about a month. The first time I used half and half instead of heavy cream, because that's what I had on hand, and the second time with the cream. Both tasted the same to me. I also used spinach one time and kale the next, and they were both very good. I omitted the onions only because I don't care for them, and I only used 3 potatoes, but they were large russet potatoes. I added the potatoes at the same time as the broth, let it boil about 10 minutes or so, then added everything else while still on high heat (including the spinach, because I liked the texture better a little more wilted) until the potatoes were soft. This is definitely one of my favorite recipes. I wonder if I could make it kid friendly but still delicious if I omitted the red pepper flakes and/or used mild sausage.

text:
Wonderful!! I forgot to add the bacon & would not even bother with it next time. By all means cook the onion & garlic with the sausage & then drain. Also, if you can't find bulk sausage, buy the packaged w/skins & simply remove. I doubled the recipe & used 1 lb mild & 1 1lb. w/fennel seeds.  Followed the advice of others & used kale, but did have some spinach already on hand to use up, so added it as well. I wanted it a bit thicker & added some instant potato flakes, which didn't change the flavor at all ... just gave it a bit more creamy texture. I garnished with a blend of grated parmesan, asiago & romano cheese & YUM!  Absolutely will make again as it was SO EASY & delicious. Corn would be a great addition to the ingredients.

city:

text:
I can't lie, I haven't had whatever 'chain restaurant' soup this is imitating. However, it's still really good. I must confess I left out the bacon because, to me, adding bacon to anything overpowers all the other flavors. So, I tend to try things with & without bacon. I also used kale instead of spinach (per reviews), and milk + cornstarch instead of cream. The "hot Italian sausage" I bought wasn't hot enough for us, so I added 1.5 tsp of crushed red pepper flakes. Also, I think 6 potatoes is a really large number... maybe really small potatoes?! I added 4 and it seemed like so many, I added extra chicken broth + upped the amount of milk I used. Ultimately I left it cooking for 40 minutes after adding the potatoes, and they were super soft - maybe more potatoes wouldn't have been bad? In any case, I really liked this soup. I let the kale sit in the soup (covered, but off, still on the hot burner) for about 15 minutes and it was really good. Next time... will try with bacon!

Great soup!!  Admission: I did change it up a bit. I thought I had spinach... apparently I used it all up last night.  Once I realized it - the soup was already half way done... so I threw in carrots and celery about 10 minutes after the potatoes went in.  Also, I didn't have heavy cream, so I used half and half.  It worked great.  The beauty of this soup is that it's flexible.  The flavor was outstanding - and I'm pretty sure it'd taste great, no matter what veggies you had on hand.

I've made this recipe many. many times.  This time I used pre-cooked turkey bacon and just threw it (and the onion and garlic)in for a few minutes after cooking the sausage (Iserno's  chicken Italian). This made the prep a little easier and less messy.

text:
I was a little concerned when I got almost all the way through cooking this and realized there isn't really any seasoning in it (I cook with a lot of herbs normally) but I assumed that most of the flavor would come from the sausage. The sausage stayed in larger chunks despite my best efforts to cut them down and it was a little overpowering. The rest of the soup had a good flavor base and the spinach was wonderful, but it just seemed to be missing something I couldn't quite put my finger on. I will certainly make this again, but will likely reduce the amount of sausage (not a big fan of it to begin with) and try to fill in the missing flavor (perhaps fresh ground pepper, some salt, maybe a little grate cheese on top?)

country:
None
text:
I love Zuppa Toscana and was happy to find a recipe. Like reviewers said, I used Kalp instead of spinach, I tore of the edges and put it in the last 10 minutes of simmering. Also I used spicy sausage. 1lb is wayyy too much sausage, next time i will only use 1/2 lb. 6 potatoes are way too much too. I only used 3 large ones and it still seemed like the soup was more of a stew. For good flavor put the sausage in the soup at the beginning instead of the end. Overall doing these things I got rave reviews for my dinner guests and I personally thought it tasted better than the restaurant style. 5 stars!!

text:
I truly expected something wonderful, based on all the reviews; I just don't get it!  I was able to rescue this soup with a few modifications.  After cooking the onions and garlic, I stirred in a few tablespoons of flour, cooking for a few minutes. Then I added the chicken broth and peeled and cubed potatoes.  I used Swiss Chard instead of spinach or kale since it's a wonderfully sweet green. Grated a half cup or so of parmigiano reggiano in so it had some flavor, otherwise this is a thin, bland soup.   It does go together quickly though, which is good, but benefits from thickening and flavor-boosting.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making this recipe for 10 years and have made different versions.  I use links and remove the skins of the italian sausage, only use 1 tsp.of the crushed pepper flakes and substitute one cup of shredded sweet potato for the regular potato for a healthier version.  Instead of cans of broth, I use two quart boxes of low sodium chicken broth and I sub thinly chopped kale for the spinach which I find has a better texture.  Also added two tablespoons of flour to half and half instead of heavy cream and shake it up to dissolve and thicken the soup.  Yummmy.

Very good! A little too greasy to me and I will definitely find a way to cook it w/less grease next time but my husband loved it as is. A tip for the spinach. city:

None
country:
None
text:
Oh my, my new favorite soup! This was absolutely amazing!  I doubled the bacon, used Italian sausage links, removed the casings and browned in the oven. I used one tsp. of the red pepper flakes and it was just the right amount of heat for me. Because it holds up so much better than spinach I used kale instead and while the onion and garlic mixture was sauteing and the sausage was browning I put my chicken stock in the soup pot and threw in my kale so it could start to cook.  Not much gets by without the addition of my usual garlic and onion powders and I also added dried parsley and black pepper. Once done, I added in Fat Free half and half and only because I thought it looked pretty, I placed a big handful of baby spinach into each bowl before ladling in the soup. Thank you so much for one terrific recipe!! Yum!!!!

region:

country:
None
text:
LOVE LOVE LOVE! It is "souper" easy to make and the perfect comfort soup. I always make a large batch to take to work for lunch. Having this at Olive Garden, to be able to make it myself, I like having full control of all the salt and cream that goes into this. I have made it with spinach and with kale. Personally I prefer using kale. It tends to have much more of a bite and the texture works very well against the smooth potato. I like to use a combination mild and hot italian sausage, which give just that extra kick along with the red pepper flakes. I can't rave enough about this soup. Make sure to serve with a baguette on the side, you will keep dipping it in that delicious broth and (almost) forget to use your spoon for the rest!

text:
We liked it. Better than good but didn’t rise to the 5* ‘love it’ category. Made as written other than using more generous portions of hot Italian sausage and bacon, and the hot, rather than mild, sausage likely kept this recipe from falling to a 3*. I now better appreciate other reviewers saying it tasted bland to them . . . not exactly bland to us but didn’t pack an expected big flavor punch for such a highly loved soup. We don’t eat a lot of Italian cuisine but the Zuppa Toscana we’ve had at independent Italian restaurants seemed to have had a bit thicker base than this one. May try tinkering with this recipe to make it more creamy but it won’t be soon as this site has many other excellent soup recipes.

This soup is AMAZING.  It really is like the soup at Olive Garden.  A few modifications--I do not use the bacon.  I use a bit less cream (I just pour it in until the soup is the right color for me.  It's probably 1/2 C of cream.)  I use kale instead of spinach, since that's what OG does.  Sometimes I use the bulk hot Italian sausage instead of the mild.  I like the extra spiciness!  I have made this so many times, and it is always wonderful!

userID:
2348670
Display Name:
handbanana
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
132
favoritesCount:
795
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made according to recipe except subbing kale for spinach.  I'm giving it three stars since the recipe as written almost failed.  What went wrong: 1) I used 6 sliced on a mandoline medium potatoes, organic from Trader Joes so I'm not sure what type they were although they were golden colored, that never turned to mush so the broth was very very thin.  Had to use my immersion (stick) blender to puree it which thickened it up a little bit.  2) Still a very thin soup so I added a cup and a half of potato flakes which saved the soup.  3) Although I drained the sausage it turned the soup orange.  After pureeing the soup it really looked like baby food.  Read other reviews after the fact and some people rinsed the cooked sausage before adding it to the soup.  I've never heard of that before and wished it had been in the directions.  Fortunately, the addition of the potato flakes helped absorb all the sausage grease floating on top so it wasn't as unappetizing as before.  4) Wait to add the red pepper flakes or use a very small amount.  I used less than the recipe called for and it was still really spicy even with using mild Italian sausage.  On a slightly positive note, it's nice to have a meal that I can sneak in some raw kale but this was not a soup for my toddler or preschooler.  My husband and I each ate 1 small bowl but as for the leftovers...it's going to take a long time to finish this soup.  The type of potato used in this soup must be the key to make it a success.

5

text:
For a more healthy twist and a completely vegetarian version, I used vegan Italian "sausage", veggie bacon, vegetable broth, and substituted milk thickened with potato starch for cream. Also, I added chopped celery and kale for more veggies. It came out great! I had the vegan meat products frozen so I grated the vegan sausage and diced the veggie bacon and let them render in olive oil and garlic until crisp to bring out the flavors. Delish!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup is the best ever!  I'm not generally a soup eater but I nearly always have a batch of this in the fridge.  Just a few minor tweaks for me - many of which were in the recipe when I received it from a friend:  I use the sage ground sausage because it's my favorite.  Rather than cook bacon, I use real bacon bits from the salad dressing section of my grocery store - cheap and easy!  I omit the onion because my roommate hates onion - don't miss it.  Rather than using chicken broth, I cook the potatoes in 12 cups of water and add four tbsp of chicken bouillon granules.  I use kale rather than spinach and, because I eat this soup so often, I no longer use the cream but have used half and half or even milk. I also use one tablespoon of the pepper  flakes because I like it spicy.  I like another reviewer's suggestion of using cauliflower in place of the potatoes.  I'll try that next time I make it.  I love, love, love this soup.  EDIT:  Tried it with the cauliflower.  Pretty darn good, I must say.  This soup is so, so wonderful!

3rd soup of 52 for the year.  And they keep getting better.  This one leaves some heat on the tongue, which I LOVE.  As usual I altered the recipe a bit as usual, but the core is there and AMAZING.  I added some asparagus, used Turkey Bacon, and didn't add any cream to make it a little healthier.  I also skimmed some of the grease off the top because the sausage and bacon can be greasy.  All together the best soup I have made ever.  The heat is great, the heartiness is awesome and I am impressed.  Might have to get another bowl as I write this.

I used hot italian sausage instead of mild and left out the red pepper flakes. The key to this recipe is a good sausage I think as that is where you get a lot of flavor. I also cooked the onions with the sausage to absord all the yummy flavor and then drained it before adding my broth. I also sliced the spuds thick to give it some body. This is my husbands favorite soup when we go out and he said he "doesn't want any of that other  ever again!" I'm guessing he liked it :)

This recipe can be easily customized to please different tastes & dietary needs. For a bolder flavor I used 2 large bouillon cubes & water instead of canned broth. I am lactose intolerant so I used lactose free milk & 3 tbsp of cornstarch instead of cream. Next time I will use the number of potatoes the recipe calls for (not less) & hot sausage and no red pepper flakes instead of mild. I forgot to add the kale and it still turned out delicious. Thanks!

Absolutely amazing.  This is an incredibly tasty soup - serve with some crusty bread to dip in the soup and a small salad and you have yourself a really delicious and filling meal.  I made an Italian caprese salad - fresh buffalo mozzarella, sliced tomatoes and fresh basil, drizzled with extra virgin olive oil and balsamic vinegar.  Also had some store-bought ciabatta bread with it.  I'm honestly going to be sad when my leftovers run out, this soup is uh-may-zing.  I'm not even kidding.  Also, I made it with the kale, not spinach - makes all the difference.  I would not make with spinach.  Try this recipe - you will NOT be disappointed.

I have made this recipe a few times now.  I modify as I need to with what I have.  We have a ton of sausage from the butcher so sometimes I cut up sausage links instead of using ground.  Sometimes I use cans of broth and other times I use homemade stock.  I tend to make my potatoes a bit bigger and when done cooking, I take a potato masher and just  lightly mash the whole soup.  I also often freeze this soup into individual servings. Made this soup for a soup exchange and it was the first soup to get picked by most everyone there.  Thanks!

Very Good! It had just the right amount of zip to it! I used 2 buches of Kal and 7 potatoes, as we like a bit more girth to our soup. Instead of heavy cream I used Lowfat Buttermilk which is half the Cholesterol of 2% milk. It has a bit more sodium though.... choose your demon. I used Bob Evans Itailian bulk sausage which has fennel and other seasonings in it. This is my favorite soup from that unnamed restaurant, and I'm almost giddy that I can make it at home now! Thanks for posting !!!

userID:
3506657
Display Name:
MrsChmerkovskiy
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

0
madeRecipesCount:
83
favoritesCount:
2
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe can be made much easier, and less of a big process by following this: Put some olive oil in a big pot, brown the garlic and onions, add the sausage and brown. While that's browning cook the bacon in the microwave until it is crispy and done.  Strain the sausage mixture, return to pot, add bacon and broth.  Let it boil, add the potatoes.  **I sliced my potatoes using my KitchenAid mixer thin slicing attachment...worked perfectly**  When the potatoes are cooked, add the cream, tear some kale up with your hands and you're set.  Next time I will try using 4 potatoes.  I did six, added almost all of them in, and there were way too many potatoes, so I scooped a lot of them out.  Then when we sat down to eat, I felt like I scooped too many out.  I think 4 small-med. potatoes would be the perfect amount.  The recipe was still delicious, and everyone liked it.  I gave it a four because I think the directions could be made much simpler by how I did it above.  Also, I used kale instead of spinach.

Exellent, re-warms well, just one suggestion, do not fry the bacon with the onions. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OOoooh my goodness, sooo tasty! There's a reason this recipe is so highly rated! I just made this soup a few days ago and have been feasting on the leftovers since then, and it only improved during its time in my fridge! I just finished it yesterday, but already I am contemplating making more.

Next time I make it I think I will either use hot italian sausage, or add more chili flakes, because I love things spicy. This soup had a kick to it, but nothing too extreme in case anyone was worried. Oh, and I also used kale instead of spinach, and it held up beautifully in my leftovers.

Also, I didn't drain the sausage as well as i should have and the grease was really orange, and made the soup less appetizing looking. I ended up cooling the soup and skimming the top layer of orange off before reheating and serving.

text:
I made this to get rid of some Italian sausage in the freezer.  It looked just like the famous restaurant’s version, but for some reason, it tasted nothing like it.  The only changes I really made (other than using kale like the restaurant does) were to use turkey bacon and low sodium chicken broth; could this have been my problem?  The soup didn’t taste bad, but it didn’t taste like the restaurant version, either.  Hmm, might have been my fault…  Well, anyway, I probably won’t make this again since I rarely buy Italian sausage as hubby is not a fan.  Thanks anyway! :)  UPDATE: I tried the soup after a night in the fridge and BOY, WHAT A DIFFERENCE!!  I think the flavors from the sausage needed to mix with the broth; that’s what was missing from the taste.  Now, the soup tastes GREAT and VERY close to the famous restaurant’s version!  I most certainly will make this again, but I will let in sit in the fridge a day or two before serving—the difference is amazing.  Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
This is a great soup!  If you love potato soup, I definitely recommend this one.  I omitted the red pepper flakes (little mouths over here).  And I used spinach, which was okay the first night, but not so good when it was reheated.  I really vacillated about using kale, but next time I will for sure.  Oh, and I would recommend peeling the potatoes (just in case you're like me and skip this step when you can).  I used a mix of russets (peeled) and reds (unpeeled) and found that the red potato skins were an annoying distraction in the soup.  We served this up with plenty of freshly cracked black pepper for that added zip.

Excellent flavor soup! I preferred to chop the potatoes, instead of slice, and chop the spinach before adding. I only liked this soup okay, and I don't think that I will be making it again. I followed the recipe exactly with two exceptions: I used spinach instead of kale, and I used half chicken broth and half water. (I suspected that with the bacon and sausage the soup would taste salty enough with some water in it, and I was right.) It was a bit too spicy for me, and the texture was a bit too thin. (It might be improved by removed the bacon before adding the liquids, cooking the potatoes as instructed, and then removing and pureeing some of the potato/onion/broth/mixture and returning it to the pot to make the whole thing thicker in consistency.)

text:
Seattle had snow today, in April (!) and I decided we needed soup.  Being as we so often have "soup days" here, I make many different kinds.  This one will go to the top of the rotation.  Absolutely wonderful.  Super-delicious, in fact!  I thought the sliced potatoes would be too big but they disolved quite a bit--it was kinda like the potato soup my mom used to make but it had meat in it, which is my men's only requirement for soup.  We liked it so much I made it again two days later to serve for dinner guests.  Wouldn't change a thing, perfect recipe.

city:

country:
None
text:
This is delicious.  I have made it many times. I have made it with hot Italian sausage and like it even better just leave out the red pepper flakes if doing that.   I cook mine in the oven then slice it up instead of removing the casings.   I have also substituted turkey bacon for regular and can't really taste that much difference.  I usually use Kale.   Use low sodium chicken broth or it gets too salty.  Half the amount of cream is plenty, or even half and half.  Once I used I can of beef broth in place of the chicken and that gave it a little more richness so loved it too.  I always add a bay leaf and a little Italian seasoning and fennel.  If making ahead of time wait and add the cream shortly before serving and don't add the Kale or spinach until about 5 minutes prior to serving.  Oh, I even used deer sausage once and it too was delicious.  This is 5 stars no matter how I have made it.  Serve with a skillet or corn bread. YUM YUM

text:
I made this soup a few days ago, and I followed the recipe pretty much to a T, with the exception of using my own homemade chicken broth, and, of course, using kale in the place of spinach.  There was one review that said you might want to slice the potatoes in two thicknesses, to allow the thinner ones to break down in the broth, and the thicker ones to retain their shape and texture.  I did this and found that even after a few days, I still have pieces of potato in the soup. Good tip! I might also be guilty of a couple extra shakes of the pepper flakes, we like a little zip!  This is the perfect recipe, and I think it's even better than the soup that's served at the restaurant. I don't need to look at any of the others, and will go to this every time I need the Zuppa Toscana fix!

text:
I have made this recipe with changes. The original recipe did not call for bacon so I will save that for my other meals. I use Johnsonville Hot Italian sausage because I want the flavor of the sausage especially when it is mixed with heavy cream. I am not a big fan of any green veggies but Kale works nicely in this dish. I added a few more potatoes and smashed a few on the side to thicken the soup. Since I am using Hot Italians, I don't need to add any hot pepper flakes and I only use Chicken broth that is low sodium. I don't make this often but when I do, I want it to taste just like it should. Since it costs $6-7 to buy a cup of this at the restaurant, I make sure that when I get a hankering to eat it, I make my own.  I would love to freeze some of it but I find that when I freeze Italian Sausage, it loses its flavor. My new bummer.

text:
I did not change much to the recipe. I normally will try to cut fat in recipes if it is saturated, such as meat and dairy. I used a hot Italian Turkey Sausage instead of pork and used fat free half and half instead of heavy cream. Everything else was the same. I liked the flavor, but found it really thin. We prefer creamier soups. First, I added grated Parmesan cheese in hopes of thickening it up. I ended up adding a can of cream of chicken soup. This worked and gave it a nice creamy base. I have a feeling this may be one of those dishes that taste even better the next day. If I made this again, I would try adding less chicken broth and more half and half.

text:
My husband and I really liked this recipe and my husband doesn't typically like soup. We made it almost as the recipe stated. We thinly sliced up the fresh spinach and added our desired amount to our bowls and crumbled bacon on top. The bacon on top added a nice crunch to the texture. We made it a second time and substituted the italian sausage and spinach with chorizo and kale and that was, dare I say, even better. We also only added the bacon on top the second time, omitted the red pepper flakes and made sure to let the kale cook down for about 30 minutes. We will definitely use this recipe again.
(Chorizo tends to be really greasy, so drain off the excess grease)

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6886266.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Make this soup now!!! Soooo delicious! I followed the recipe except for using kale instead of spinach (that's what the famous restaurant uses!) and added the kale about 6-7 minutes from the potatoes being done, before adding the sausage and cream into the pot. I used 6 small/medium sized red potatoes and took another reviewer's suggestion to cut a couple of them thinner than the others. This allows the thin ones to break apart and help thicken the soup, while the thicker ones hold their shape. Very quick and easy to do with a mandolin slicer. I thought the seasonings were perfect. No need to make changes! If you don't want your soup to turn orange, give the cooked sausage a quick rinse under very hot water to remove the excess fat. A keeper!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2014-03-05T23:38:33.933
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
13270688
Display Name:
Emily S
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good, but needed some help. This makes a LOT of soup, so unless you have a lot of people eating it, I suggest cutting back. I made about a half batch. I don't really measure much, either. I used about a half pound of Jimmy Dean hot sausage, 2 strips of bacon, and half an onion.I follow the recipe except I don't use garlic and I don't add the bacon into the soup. I add whatever broth (homemade) I have on hand and add water to make 4 cups of liquid. It's usually about half and half. I also add the red pepper flakes here as well as garlic powder (since I don't keep real garlic on hand) salt and pepper from a grinder, and whatever else smells good from the spice cabinet (usually cayenne pepper, paprika, stuff like that). As for the potatoes, I use 2 large russets. Leave the skin on, cut them in half and half again lengthwise. I cut them about a quarter inch thick, some thinner to help thicken the broth, and add them in. I bring it all to a boil rather than bringing it to a boil THEN adding the potatoes. I let it simmer down for about 10-15 minutes after they're done to thicken it up. I add half a cup of cream and a good amount of kale, rather than spinach. I've used spinach and it turns to mush on me. After it's reheated to almost a boil, I serve it and crumble the bacon over top of it with some parmesan. Sooo yummy. It usually makes 3-4 servings. Since it's only 2 people that eat it in my house, including me, there are leftovers and they reheat well.

text:
This was AMAZING! I will definitely be adding this to my normal rotation. I did however make a few adjustments. I used reduced sodium chicken broth based on other feedback and added salt to taste. I used four large russet potatoes instead of six. Used spicy Italian sausage instead and added less red pepper flakes. I also used Kale instead of spinach and omitted the bacon because I didn't need the extra calories. Will definitely be making again!

text:
I absolutely loved this! Better than the restaurant's version! My tweaks, used turkey bacon (less fat and sodium), added fennel seed (1 TBS), used 2 large cans of chicken broth (48oz) (this makes the proportion to the potatoes and sausage perfect for me, plus tons of leftovers for freezing), doubled the garlic, and substituted kale for spinach. I will say I only added the Kale to each bowl before serving because the first time I made it, the kale was a bit mushy with leftovers. This way it's perfect every time!

text:
Great soup!  I used closer to 1/4c of minced garlic (we love garlic!) and about 3T butter in place of the bacon (we don't love bacon :P).  I sliced the potatoes nearly paper thin with my mandolin, took the pot off the burner while they were not quite done and allowed the soup to mellow for about an hour before reheating slightly and adding the spinach.  Served with some freshly ground pepper and parmesan reggiano on top, the only other thing this soup needed was a crusty french bread for wiping our bowls clean!

text:
We made this and threw in some carrots because we like carrots in our soups.  We browned the hot sausage and onions in the pressure cooker, added the broth, garlic, spinach, potatoes and carrots and cooked on high pressure for 7 minutes.  I forgot about the bacon by accident.  When the pressure cooker was done, released the pressure and added the light cream (all we had in the house) to it.  Absolutely delicious!

text:
This is indeed super delicious!  I accidentally bought sweet Italian sausage, so I upped the crushed red pepper a bit.  I also replaced the spinach with kale, just because I had some extra kale lying around.  I used my own canned broth, which is salt-free, so I added a pinch of salt and also a bit of pepper.  I also ended up adding another cup of cream, because kale does not wilt and cook down as much as spinach, and I wanted it a bit more...soupy.  This is AMAZING!  My whole family loved it, and already an argument has broken out over who gets the leftovers!  Needless to say, this will be a staple here.  Next time I will try it as written- with the regular sausage and the spinach.  I also think spicy sausage would be excellent in this.  Thanks for sharing souporsweets :)

None
country:
None
text:
This is SO good and one of my favorite recipes on this site! I've never had the chain version but I don't need to after having this. I think this serves a few more than 6 though as described above. I've got a Dutch Oven full of the stuff so these would be 6 very large servings. Good to freeze too which is nice! The quality of this soup is going to depend on the quality of your ingredients. Buy top end sausage from a butcher rather than the commercial stuff in the standard supermarket meat case. Don't buy cheap bacon....buy some thick dry rub cut varieties! I would recommend skimming the fat off the top of the soup to keep it creamier looking (and a tiny bit healthier).

text:
This tastes just like the restaurant version!  Very spicey, so if you like your soup a bit more mild, leave out the red pepper flakes.  I used the spinach, as per the recipe.  I used 6 large russet potatoes, and had to add another can of broth.  It made way more than 6 servings, I'd say more like 10, and it heats up well.  I decided to dice my potatoes so that they would stay together, instead of fall apart in the soup.  A definate keeper.

userID:
2504436
Display Name:
bluemeday
isPro:

followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
33

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I omitted the bacon and don't think it made a difference in flavor. The sausage gives it plenty of flavor! I simmered it on low and periodically skimmed off the fat on top.

I used low-sodium chicken broth and substituted the cream for 1 cup of milk instead and it was still creamy and tasty. If I had wanted even more broth, I would have just added more milk.

I wasn't sure how much kale to substitute for at first. You really need only about a stalk or two, with the leaves torn off into small pieces.  To be honest, the ratio of ingredients to stock isn't really proportional (ie: there's a lottt of ingredients compared to the amount of broth), but I was afraid to add water for fear of taking away the flavor.

Next time, I'd cut the sausage in half - 1/2 a pound is plenty (but according to the hubby, I should keep it at a full pound, so we'll see. He also thought the ratio of ingredients to broth was fine - apparently at unnamed restaurant, it's supposed to be heavier on the ingredients side than broth). I think I could have gotten away with using a "lighter" sausage - I might try using turkey sausage next time.

text:
Excellent flavor but a bit thin.  I added some cornstarch mixed with a bit of chicken broth and that thickened it up nicely.  I didn't have cream so I used 1/2 & 1/2, that may have been the problem with thickening.  Also, I just added about 1/4 package of frozen chopped spinach instead of the fresh and that worked out just fine.  I'll make this again for sure.  Thanks for posting your recipe souporsweets!

text:
This soup was fantastic!  I used hot turkey sausage and turkey bacon to lower the fat content.  Also used 1/2 c. half and half and 1/2 c. milk.  As others suggested, I also used kale in place of the spinach.  I only used 2 large potatos, this was more than enough.  And next time I would use 1 or 2 cans of lower sodium chicken broth.  It was a little too salty even for me.. a true salt lover!   I wish I could say how well it did after freezing it but there was nothing left to freeze!  Delish!!

text:
This is a great base for a soup recipe.  I made it much meater but healthier at the same time.  I used 1.5 lbs of bulk spicy chicken sausage and double the bacon but used uncured from Whole Foods.  The fat and cholesterol is much lower.  a 16oz serving comes to 270 cal and only 7g of fat.  I also used fingerling potatos and a red onion.

text:
Thought that this was VERY Good. Made as few changes as I was able to. The soup turned out extremely salty the way I made it.... Otherwise, it would have been truly excellent. We always use Better Than Bouillon for soup stocks. It would have been much better to have used a low sodium broth or stock. Also, I used fresh Italian Sausage from the local grocery that has always seemed a little salty. A lower sodium sausage would also have been much better. The recipe shows only 6 servings but should serve many more. I doubled the recipe to have leftovers and wished that I had made only a single batch. We will DEFINITELY have this again as the whole family loved it. I'll just try to lower the salt content a little next time.

text:
This soup is amazing!  If you love the one that the Olive Garden makes, then rest assured that this one is even more delicious.  The only change I make is I use an entire (small) package of bacon, which is 6-7 slices.  Who doesn't love more bacon, right?!  Slice your potatoes nice and thin so they crumble up after they cook.  Also, use a high-quality sausage... it really does make a difference.  Thanks for the recipe!!!

text:
This is going to become a regular at my house for sure. I had to adapt this to what I had on hand.... I used ground turkey (seasoned w/ fennel seeds, red pepper flakes, cumin, sage, margoram, onion and garlic powder so it would taste like sausage), I used half the amount of chicken stock andabout 3 cups of fat free milk (plus 1/4 cup of corn starch) in place of the heavy cream. I also left out the bacon and only used 2 potatos I cubed. This was good with some parmesan cheese on top. Thanks for sharing!

text:
WOW! This is way better than the chain soup. I made before work one day and brought it in for everyone in a crockpot. People couldn't get enough! Slicing the potatoes in a food processor and chopping the onion in a food processor made this a quick recipe. I used a 1 lb. sausage roll, which was very good. (had one in the freezer) Heavy cream as well as milk with cornstarch (as suggested by another review) made the consistancy excellent. For the bacon, I had the bag of chopped, cooked bacon - so that was handy and less fatty.  Served with french bread, salad. This is a keeper!!

Excellent! This recipe rocks!!! To make a little healthier I did substitute ground turkey for the sausage and replace the cream with non-fat milk. Due to time issues, I cooked all the ingredients as directed (but a little less time) and then threw ingredients into a slowcooker and placed on low. This was great because it was hot and ready when we finally had time to eat. Just before serving I added 1/3C heavy cream and 2/3C non-fat milk and fresh spinach. It was met with great reviews from everyone in the family! Thanks for Sharing!

text:
This soup is amazing, but I would never make this with spinach! Kale is a must in this recipe. I've been making similar recipes for 6 years. The texture and flavor of kale are perfect here, if you've never had it, think romaine lettuce mixed with parsley. Also needed a bit of salt and parmesan cheese for my taste. This might be due to the fact that I crumble the bacon and add it in with the sausage so it's not all mushy in the soup. I always use hot Italian sausage, the flavor is better to me. I still add the pepper flakes. We live in a spicy household! I would give it a 5 except the broth did need a flavor kick with the salt and parm, and the lack of KALE!

text:
This came out well - although there was only 1/2 pound turkey sausage in my freezer which crumbled well after removing the casing. The second change I made was 8 slices bacon, cut into  pieces - because the chicken broth was salt free. If I make this again, I'll dice the potatoes - the thin slices were hard to eat with a spoon. The third change was to use a cup of fat free half and half.  Thanks for sharing.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/14.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup is fantastic.  I made some changes to make it Weigh Watcher's friendly and it was great.  I love the original version at Olive Garden (I had a roommate in college who worked there and would bring some home for me a couple of times a week) and it was super close!  The changes I made were: I used Jennie-O Italian Seasoned Ground Turkey instead of italian sausage (I also added a bit of fennel seed to give it more of an italian sausage flavor), I also subbed a 50/50 mix of fat free evaporated milk and fat free milk instead of the heavy whipping cream, reduced sodium chicken broth, Jennie-O Extra Lean Turkey Bacon and I used flat leaf parsley instead of spinach because thats what I had on hand.  It was fabulous and 4 points a serving for any other WW's out there!

userID:
1516436
Display Name:
Creme Brulee
isPro:
False
followersCount:
10
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
15
favoritesCount:
286
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/263883.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this soup and everyone LOVED it!  My mother-in-law took some to work; her employees said it smelled wonderful, so she gave each person a sample.  They all lined up with their plastic spoons and got a taste, then they begged for the recipe!  Zuppa Toscana is my favorite at the popular restaurant, so now I can have it anytime at home!  I make a few changes to the recipe.  I use kale instead of spinach.  Kale doesn't get mushy like spinach does, and it brings an irreplaceable freshness and crunch to the soup.  The first time I made it, there was an excess of sausage, so either add more vegetables, or cut back on the meat by 1/4-1/2, depending on your personal taste.  Finally, Hubby likes the bacon crumbled and I agree; square cut bacon detracts from the rustic feel of the soup.  Otherwise, it's fabulous as is!  Another tip: if you have those small packages of red pepper flakes from your last pizza night, 1 1/2 packages are the perfect amount for the zuppa. You'll see: people will be asking you for the recipe, too!  Homemade soup, salad, and breadsticks, here we come!

text:
****EDIT 3/2010****
I've now made this several times and have it down.  I use reduced sodium chicken broth + about 1/3C  of regular chicken broth.  I then completely omit the bacon and use spice pork sausage.  To up the spice I use about 1/8-1/4tsp of cayenne.  It turns out just right.  I use just over the required amount of cream, and use Kale instead of spinach.  OH! I also use Red Potatoes.

It's not too salty anymore, and frankly is better than the soup at the restaurant.
******************************************

My husband loved this soup and he is NOT a soup person.  We both feel that it is better than the OG version.  HOWEVER, it's a bit salty.  I think that all the canned chicken broth is the culprit (I even used low salt/sodium).  Next time I make this I think I'll go half and half on the broth/water.  Otherwise, WONDERFUL!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this recipe with spicy hot Italian sausage (because hubby brought it home by mistake) and reduced the red pepper flakes by two-thirds.  I also substituted kale for the spinach.  It was still a bit spicy for me (the men in the family loved it), but I think with a milder sausage it would be perfect.  The broth really had a good flavor.  It didn't thicken up as much as I expected, but I think you could mash a few of the potato slices to thicken it up if you wanted a thicker soup.

Edit: After years of making this recipe, I add extra greens, use large potatoes and omit the cream. The cream is a thickener, but adds nothing to the flavor of the soup.

text:
I LOVED this soup!

I used spinach because couldn't find kale.  I bought the kind in the bag and just added it until it looked right.  I also used low sodium chicken broth but needed to add salt in the end.  

I also used only 1 tsp of red pepper flakes and it was perfect.

I found that it did not freeze and reheat well - the second time around the bacon was chewy and the potatoes were completely crumbled and mashed.

BUT, over all it was delicious and I would definitely make it again!

text:
I have made this at least fifty times now.  My family makes me make it at LEAST once a week.  This is what I do to make everyone go back for thirds: Use the hot Italian sausage in the casings (the ground beef looking stuff has an inferior texture).  I use extra red pepper flakes to make it spicier.  Extra garlic makes it yummier.  Finally, I substitute kale for spinach... The Kale is chewier, but it doesn't shrivel up, and adds a lot of texture.  This soup has made me famous.  Thank you!

text:
Finally a soup the kids love.  I tweaked a little. I only used 2 cans of chk broth because I like it thicker and don't want the potatoes to over cook.  I used new potatoes vs. russets. Tried both ways and the consistency of the new potatoes is much better. Make sure you add the bacon or it will be bland but if you forget salt to taste (speaking from experience) I have made this soup several times and it is always a favorite.  It is better than the Zuppa Toscana at Olive Garden.

text:
I absolutely love this soup and it is easy to make. I use kale removed from the central stem and add it  
 raw to individual bowls. Then pour the hot soup right over it.  I think it is important to cut the potatoes paper-thin, as directed for the best texture. Next time, I want to add about a tsp of fennel to the soup.  Our family leaves out the red pepper flakes because of sensitivity. Instead, I use bacon that is coated with ground black pepper.

Great flavor!  SOOO delicious!  To me, it's better than the restaurant version.  I have made this several times for family and gatherings.  People always like it. I used spinach and I have used kale.... I like using both - it just depends on if I want the fiber texture of kale or the silky soft wilted spinach.  One important note is that the quality of flavor is largely determined by the quality of the Italian sausage used.

text:
It turned out great. I used hot italian sausage instead of mild, and left out the crushed red peppers to compensate. My roommate said it was still too spicy, but he's kind of a wimp about that sort of thing. One thing that I don't see most reviews saying is that in addition to be super easy, this recipe is incredibly cheap to make. The most expensive thing is the sausage, and even that isn't bad if you shop around. I estimate the price to be right around $10 to make the first time, and then significantly less after, since most of the ingredients can be bought in bulk. (Especially if you use Chicken Bouillon to make your own broth)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup is AMAZING! It’s so simple but filled with flavor! If you love the Zuppa Toscana soup at Olive Garden then you will love this soup too! After reading other reviews I did make a few alterations. I added 1 teaspoon of fennel seed while cooking the itialian sausage (be sure to rinse the cooked sausage under water to avoid your soup turning orange), cut back the red pepper flakes to 1/2 teaspoon, and only cut up 4 potatoes instead of 6 (that was plenty of potatoes in the soup).  Slicing the potatoes thinly only required 5-7 minutes of cook time not 20!! I would 100% make this soup again, soooo yummy!!!!!!

text:
I had some kale and chicken sausage on hand and decided to look up a recipe.  This one looked easy and had lots of good reviews so I chose it.  I didn't have bacon so I omitted it.  After reading lots of reviews I decided to use half n half instead of heavy cream and greatly reduce the red pepper flakes and it turned out great.  I also added 1 rib of celery and 2 carrots as well to add some fiber and vitamins and grated in some fresh nutmeg (I always use it for cream based sauses).  My husband loved it and so did I.  I will definitely make this again.

text:
So... spinach? Nope, kale. Also how can you possibly boil 6 potatoes in 2.75 c liquid, soup for 2 with 6 potatoes?! What I did...
30 oz. Chx broth
2 c heavy cream 
2 handfuls of chopped kale (I'm italian we dont really measure)
Salt n pepper to taste
Now you have soup for 4 or more!

Amazing. I can't handle spicy at all so I omitted the red pepper flakes. I added 1 1/2 tsp fennel as recommended by some other reviewers and cubed my potatoes instead of thinly slicing them. The soup is a tad salty so I would recommend using low sodium broth next time but there definitely will be a next time. Pairs well with crusty bread.

country:
None
text:
Five stars because this worked so well. I made my own adjustments to it and I think it came out better than the chain version. I used spicy Italian sausage, only 3 big russet potatoes, and kale instead of spinach. I also used a box of broth then filled the pot with water and two teaspoons of caldo de pollo, this prevented the soup from getting too salty. The spicy sausage replaces the red peppers and really seasons the whole soup. Next time I’ll replace one of the potatoes for cauliflower!

This soup was delicious.  I found it accidentally by putting in an ingredient search of leftover items I wanted to use up.  It was something different from the norm, took less than an hour, and was filling.  We served it with homemade honey wheat bread, pomello (citrus fruit), and Caesar salad.
The consistency was that of creamy broth so if you like a thicker soup base, you may want to add a thickener.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6304741.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this tonight with a few minor modifications.  After reading an earlier review I rinsed my Italian sausage in hot water to prevent the soup from turning red. Glad that I did.  I used kale instead of Spinach. I used half-and-half instead of heavy cream and I added cornstarch to thicken it up a bit. I also used a few more red pepper flakes because I like it a tad bit spicy. And I must say it is delicious!  Very pleased!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
This was delicious!  The only changes made were we added 4 more bacon slices that I oven baked earlier that day. You can never go wrong with more bacon, right?  Browned the sausage on the stovetop and chunked it up. Initially I was planning on draining the grease off the sausage, but it seemed fairly lean so added the onion to the sausage mixture and then the other ingredients. A great hearty soup!  Serve with a crusty loaf of bread...enjoy!

This recipe needs way more spice. Use more red pepper flakes and minced garlic. Use kale instead of spinach. Use Jimmy Dean Italian Pork Sausage (ground). Don't skip the onions- you'll need the flavor. Double the bacon. It takes about an hour or a little over to cook the potatoes enough in the crockpot on high heat.

Review:

userID:
24719409
Display Name:
Michelle Vello
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6102090.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow. There’s a reason why this has 4,000 reviewers with 4,000 different palates  and yet it’s still a 5-star recipe. 

My suggestions:

1. Omit the potatoes. You don’t need them. I use slightly more of the added other ingredients to make up for it. 
2. Don’t skip the heavy cream. You will miss the richness of the dish. It’s hilarious that so many people sub the heavy cream for milk and tbsps of flour and yet gorge on potatoes. Heavy cream is good for you, folks. Potatoes aren’t. 
3. Halve the amount of red pepper. It still gives a slight kick without overpowering the rest of the flavours. 
4. Rather than dice or chop your potatoes, blitz them in a food processor until they’re VERY finely chopped but not yet purée. Sautée them in the bacon fat on medium-low (but closer to low) for 15-20 minutes before proceeding. 
5. Take out the bacon once it’s cooked and put it off to the side with the sausage. 
6. Sub kale for spinach. Don’t even think about using spinach. Becomes wayyyy too slimy. Of course it takes awhile to break down the kale so add it into the soup and then simmer it for 20 minutes. 

Also, how the heck can people low score this recipe for “blandness”? Add salt or bouillon, taste, and repeat until flavourful for your palate. LOL. Not rocket science.

userID:
8263506
Display Name:
Justin Collins
isPro:
False
followersCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6032897.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup at OG is my favorite soup in the WORLD, so I had to find the recipe and make it.  I will say this recipe is about 99% great...  Only a couple changes I’d suggest..
1) If you have an Instant Pot, use it!  It’s great to make this delicious soup in an hour or less and have it taste like it’s been simmering and the flavors mixing all day!  
2) As a previous poster mentioned, this recipe leaves out the Fennel Seed that is in the OG recipe.  The Fennel is very important to get the nuanced flavor you get at the restaurant.  Also, lightly crush the Fennel Seeds to release their flavor before adding.
3) I’d definitely use hot Italian sausage instead of mild.  Of course the level of heat will come down to personal preference, but the hot sausage will make this more like the restaurant soup.
4) The original version does use kale, not spinach.  I find the kale to be tastier than spinach as well as more in line with the original recipe.
5) Be sure to use russet potatoes.  This is what the restaurant uses, and when cooked in soup they tend to make it creamier than other strains of potatoes.
6) I’d also recommend using Better Than Bouillon Chicken soup base as opposed to your average chicken stock - but I’d encourage using BTB over regular stock in ANY soup or dish that calls for stock or broth.

Other than those little adjustments, great recipe!  I could eat this multiple times a week and I’m not sure I’d ever get sick of it lol

text:
This is best version of the Tuscan soup. My family and our friends we enjoy it every time. It is a little heavier than recommended if you watch your figure, but for once in a while you deserve to spoil yourself. I made this soup following this exact recipe for quite few times now. The more I make it the better it is. I no longer cook the bacon, sausage and the onion separate. I first put the bacon in the pan, then I add the sausage and at last the onion and garlic. I let them to saute until the all juice is reduced and the meet becomes crispy. I did not change the rest of the steps. Try it! Is excellent!

userID:
1518847
Display Name:
Leisl Kern
isPro:
False
followersCount:
6

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1154212.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think this is a good starting point for a recipe that is easily modified to suit anyone's taste.

I used a 5 qt dutch oven and it was very full when it was finished. I would say that it easily makes 8 (2 cup) servings).

I made the following modifications:
-Kale instead of spinach (8 oz package, stems removed) (I added it with the cream and the sausage and cooked for about 5 minutes to soften.
-Potatoes (1.5 pounds, skin-on russets, cut in large, but bite-sized chunks)
-Half-n-half instead of heavy cream (actually, I used what cream I had in the fridge (about 1/4 cup) and the rest half-n-half)
-1/2 tsp red pepper flakes instead of 1-1/4 tsp (next time I would add a little more. My kids said they would like a little more spice, but 1-1/4 would probably be too much for my kids.)
-Chicken broth, I used 40 oz. I thought the 5 cans would be too much.

Next time I might leave out the bacon. I don't think the famous restaurant has it in theirs.

text:
I like this soup so much!  I had it at a restaurant and it was a little on the thin side, but when your making it yourself, things like that are easily changed.  The only changes I made was to add a little more potato, sausage, a little less of the red pepper (to much spice is not my friend) and left out the kale or spinach.  I didn't like the kale used in the restaurant's version.  Whenever I got a bite of it in the soup, it made for a very unappetizing texture and taste so I'll get my veggies at a different meal.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5801215.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was such a flavorful soup! I did as others suggested - used half of the potatoes, omitted the bacon, added 1 tsp. fennel seeds to the sausage when cooking, and substituted kale for the spinach. Instead of the mild sausage and red pepper flakes I used 1/2lb mild sausage and 1/2lb hot sausage. This gave the perfect amount of heat, for me, but the red from the hot sausage did give the soup a red tinge, which was a little off-putting. Next time I may use the mild sausage/red pepper flakes instead. Also, the soup was a little more liquidy than I think it should have been. That may have been me, as I was worried about overcooking the potatoes and maybe could have let it all simmer longer to become creamier. All in all it was a delicious soup and one my family voted as a keeper. Thank you for posting it!

city:

text:
We loved this soup!  It tastes like our favorite soup at Olive   Gardens.  I used low-sodium chicken broth and substituted
low-fat evaporated milk in place of the heavy cream.  After browning the onions and sausage, I placed them in a colander and ran hot water over them to reduce the fat. I have made this recipe several times and by tweaking it I don't feel so guilty about fixing it.  You can also use the packaged pre-cooked and crumbled bacon to save time.  I also cut the potatoes into small cubes instead of slicing them.  I'm planning on making this often.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
So good and easy. I skipped some steps and reduced the amount overall since cooking for one. So, sliced up one mild Italian sausage and 2 slices of bacon together along with red chilli flakes. When they were almost cooked added diced onion and garlic. A few minutes later added 4cups chicken broth - low sodium- brought to a boil. Then added small bite size chunks of potato (not slices but chunks and only from one potato in this reduced size recipe. When they were cooked added spinach and splash of half and half. Served with sour dough bread and butter. Made 3-4 servings.  Yum! Took only 20-30 minutes from start to finish max. Will make again.

I was going to make Italian Wedding Soup and this happened to pop up.  This is one of my favorite soups--ever!  My subs (only because I was going to make Italian Wedding Soup)  I use escarole-instead of kale or spinach.  I didn't add bacon. Made my own stock,  and I caramelized the onions and garlic and it's alllllllll delicious  I will be making this forever.  Just upped the flakes and I added both hot sausage and sweet and just a half a cup of cream.

region:

country:
None
text:
I made the recipe according to the instructions, but made a few tweeks per the suggestion of other reviewers. I used 1 tsp fennel seed and used milk with 3 Tbsp of cornstarch. I also used chopped frozen kale instead of fresh. The kids prefer it bc they couldn't taste the kale like in the original soup. I just used a small amounting kale in the soup for some color. Too much can overwhelm it. I thought everything tasted great, but there was something missing. I couldn't put my finger on it, but the broth seemed a little bland. maybe if I had simmered the sausage in the broth longer or added some salt it would have been better. It makes a lot of soup so maybe after the ingredients have marinated together, it would be good. I also used low sodium broth so that may be the reason, not too sure. Overall it was still very good and I will make it again

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Man is this delicious!  I followed the recipe "almost" to a T :)   I used 8 pieces of bacon instead of 4, because...duh....bacon!  :)  I also used Kale instead of spinach because thats what I had on hand (though my friend makes it with spinach and its tasty that way too).  I also added a little bit of fennel seasoning to it.  I sliced half the potatoes thin and half thicker, so that some would break up in the soup making it thicker, but there would still be some bigger chunks.  And those were my changes.  This soup is really good with some croutons sprinkled on top if you dont have bread to serve with it and a little fresh parmesan cheese.  I will make this a regular soup in our rotation!  My 11 year old daughter loves this stuff!  Thanks for sharing!
I wanted to add that one time I replaced evaporated milk with heavy cream because I didnt have any...and that has worked out great too :)

Great, satisfying soup, and enough to eat from all week :) I served it with crusty dinner rolls.

text:
I had never had this soup at the restaurant, so I didn't know what to expect. Wow! It was delicious! Only slight changes (especially since I was cutting down on the quantity).

 I used hot Italian turkey sausage, browned it, drained it and set aside. Wiped out the skillet and cooked the bacon, drained it and set aside.  Sauted onion, then garlic. And then I threw it all into a big pot with broth and potatoes, cooked for about 30 minutes and threw in 2 C. of kale (every other recipe used kale--I have never cooked with it). Added 1/2 &1/2 after the kale wilted. I had used my mandolin to cut thin slices of russets and they held their shape. Can't wait for leftovers tonight!

text:
This soup reminds me of a soup I had at Marios in Florence IT
I made a few changes to increase the similarity.  Added about 1/4 cup boars head tavern ham, cayenne instead of red pepper flakes,  one cup paremesan cheese, baby spinach 5 oz plastic tub, 4 cups chicken broth, 4 cups chicken stock.   I used unsalted broth and stock, did not add any salt at all.   It's salty enough from the sausage, ham, bacon and cheese.   
Another change I will try next time is cannelloni beans instead of potatoes.   This soup is great and easy to personalize

text:
This is a great recipe, definitely a do-over!  It's fast and easy to make, and tastes better than the restaurant.  Don't slice your potatoes too thin, or they will disintegrate during cooking.  I used russet potatoes (unpeeled), Johnsonville Hot Italian sausage links (sliced) and Swanson chicken broth.  The hot sausage, combined with the red pepper flakes, gives the soup a wonderful spicy flavor.  I also used Kale, instead of spinach.  Absolutely a winner.
