https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I signed up to the site just to review this recipe.  I've made it several times over the last couple years, always returning to this site for the basic recipe ingredients, and I've been making minor tweaks here and there to try different things.  First of all, if you're new to cooking, don't be daunted.  This is super easy to make, doesn't take all day, and the people you serve will definitely love it!  It's very much worth the effort!

My tips below are just what I've learned from the people I've served this to:

The first thing I've found is USE GOLDEN POTATOES.  Thinly sliced, the texture of these, and the lower starch content, is preferable.  Russet potatoes are cheaper.  But you'll be happier with golden potatoes.  Use 7-8 golden potatoes, depending on size, over the 6 russets, since they're smaller.

Second, buy mild ground sausage.  Don't buy links unless you want to cut away the "skin" and pull out the meat one link at a time.  I say mild because not everyone likes spicy.  I do, but my kids don't.  It's easier to adjust the spice with the added crushed red pepper flakes.  Speaking of which, if you forget to add those flakes to the sausage while cooking, they can be added to the onions while cooking those.  No difference in the end result.  Start with a smaller amount of flakes and adjust upwards next time you cook if you can handle it.

Third, nix the bacon, but do use bacon fat for cooking the onions & garlic.  The actual bacon doesn't affect a large pot of soup so m

text:
Yum. I highly suggest starting with less red pepper flakes. I used 1/2 teaspoon and it was just right for my husband and me who like a kick, but definitely too spicy for my kiddos. Next time I will probably use just 1/4 teaspoon. Additionally, I omitted the potatoes and added tortellini. I cooked the onions/garlic/sausage/bacon all together, then added the broth and cooked the tortellini for a few minutes, then added cream, heated through, then added spinach just before serving. Delicious, quick, and easy. I will certainly make this again, thanks for the recipe!

text:
AMAZING. I needed an Italian soup to go with our dinner party theme and it was a hit!
I made a few changes - I used spicy sausage and omitted red pepper flakes. After the sausage was done I rinsed thoroughly in HOT water to get rid of a lot of the grease. I made way less than the recipe called for and it was just too much for 4 people. I used 3 cans broth and only 3 potatoes. I also only used 1/2 a cup of cream. I used kale instead of spinach; added the kale just before serving and it was perfect, still a little crunch! Next time I will use low sodium broth and let the guests add to taste.

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-01-02T20:26:28.437
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
11191817
Display Name:
val
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
21
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Recommendations:  
1. Cook Bacon until VERY CRISP almost burnt, the softer the bacon the soggier it will be in the soup when you eat it.
2. Stir in sausage 1st and let it sit for a minute BEFORE adding cream, this will allow the grease and any orange spice to rise to the top -spoon it out THEN add the cream - or else your cream will be greasy/orange.
3. If you are not a lover of cream - use a lighter cream or use less cream - I wish I had added 1/2 cup then slowly added until the amount was right. 1 cup was too creamy for me.
4.  Do not mix in the greens - instead I bought bundles of kale and spinach and allowed my family to pick their greens of choice, put their greens in their bowl and add the hot soup on top. The soup is so hot it will cook the greens to tenderness in their bowls and this allows for kids who don't want greens as well as offering variety!  
P.S. - we like spicy food- I used HOT spicy sausage as well as double the asked pepper flakes and this was still considered mild in our house. My kids were adding hot sauce to it - go figure.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-01-01T00:41:17.437
helpfulCount:

text:
I LOVE THIS RECIPE! My husband is always begging me to make it. I make it everytime family from Mexico comes as well. It's very easy to make as well!

The only thing I would change from this recipe is the amount of bacon grease used.. I actually wouldn't use any of the bacon grease at all! Yes, you should still cook your bacon to add the bacon bits to your soup but that grease is not needed. The sausage already has enough grease for flavor (even after draining).

Also, I use kale instead of spinach. Don't get me wrong, I love spinach with almost everything and anything but the kale is crunchier.

Turned out great! So much flavor for not adding hardly any seasoning. I didn't use much red pepper flakes because the little people in my family don't like too much heat, but I'm sure the full amount would be tasty.  I also only did half an onion. I added the cooked bacon in last and used kale (like the famous restaurant uses) instead of spinach. I really think the dutch oven is key in holding the flavors from the sausage and bacon. I overcooked the potatoes a bit because I let the soup simmer for a few hours while at a volleyball game, but everyone still loved it. Will be making again in the future!

country:
None
text:
This is almost a 5 for me, but a few things in the directions made it more difficult than it needed to be.  #1 I wouldn't cook the bacon with the onions... onions cook faster than bacon and you are to remove the bacon from the onions before  adding the garlic.  But now you bacon has pieces of onion on it.  I would cook the bacon in the microwave and use the bacon grease to cook the onion and garlic.  #2 I could cube the potatoes vs. slice.  Although one of my guests loved the slices - thought it was different.  If you go with the slices be sure to break up the potatoes before serving.  There's not much broth so don't be shy about adding more water and or chicken broth.

text:
I love this soup so much, even more than Olive Garden's version. I have made it countless times with very few changes. I substitute a dash of cayenne for the red pepper flake since I prefer that taste. I also drain the onion on a paper towel after sautéing it in the bacon grease because I feel like it ends up a little too greasy without doing so, even after draining most of it the first time. I also use kale instead of spinach, and I only add it into individual servings instead of the whole pot to keep it from becoming too wilted with reheatings. Awesome recipe!

userID:
4803976
Display Name:
moogrl217
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
7
favoritesCount:
343
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe as written was fine, but it was really great after some modifications. I've had the original version at the famous restaurant that shall remain nameless. Based on that, I left out the bacon and substituted kale for the spinach. I know the original version has sliced potatoes, but they're so unwieldy while trying to eat your soup with a spoon. I recommend cubing the potatoes, but you may have to let them cook longer.

This soup is so much better when you use spicy Italian sausage rather than the sweet sausage + red pepper flakes. Also, the amount of potato in this recipe is WAY off - we only needed about 3.5 medium-sized potatoes. We ended up having to almost double the liquid to make up for the huge volume of solid ingredients. I suggest measuring out the liquid ingredients first. Then, while you're chopping potatoes, just keep an eye on your final volume and decide "does this look like an absurd quantity of potatoes for this amount of liquid?" If yes, then STOP! Wish I had told my husband this before assigning him to chop vegetables... I ended up with a mountain of potatoes piled up in a pathetically small amount of soup.

After the modifications I described, this was a huge hit with my picky family.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-08-24T20:38:32.26
helpfulCount:
0

region:

country:
None
text:
This really is "Super-Delicious"! Here are my tips :) First,  make sure to add the bacon at the end (with the sausage) or it will be soggy/ bland.  Second, use kale instead of spinach. Third, I used one 32 ounce container of  Swanson's low sodium chicken broth, 3/4 cup water, and 3/4 cup heavy whipping cream (there would have been way too much broth and not enough substance).  And finally, I prefer to use red potatoes.  With these adjustments it is a sure crowd pleaser and tastes just like the real thing! Enjoy!!

text:
I really like it. I'm pretty good with soup, so I knew I would have to adjust the 6 potatoes. I made sure they were rather small and it worked fine. I used organic russet and sliced on the very thin setting of my Cuisineart food processor. They fell apart at 18 minutes, so next time I may use a different potato since I prefer this thinness. I added red pepper flakes at the end. I used 2% milk and though it tasted great, it wasn't as "white" and pretty as I would have liked. I definitely knew I didn't want spinach in this soup so I used bagged pre-chopped kale and tore it into smaller pieces. About two handfuls. Be careful with the potatoes. Use smallish ones. Very delicious. Could omit bacon for sure.

userID:
6962124
Display Name:
rledsworth
isPro:
False

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Okay I did rate it with a 5 because it is definitely a good recipe. I made a few changes with mine only because I didn't have everything that it called for. For a start I used regular Jimmy Dean sausage in a tube, 1 lb as the recipe called for. Once browned, I sliced half of a large red onion, a whole onion would have been fine as well, I was just lazy, so only cut up half. Then I sliced 4 medium sized yellow gold potatoes and threw them in the large skillet. I used 2 chicken and herb bullion cubes with 6 cups of scalding hot water to help dissolve them. If you'd like, you can do this earlier in the recipe so that it has sufficient time to dissolve. I did not have any broth or any unthawed chicken to make broth, which actually worked great, and I'm not a huge bullion user. Cook on medium for about 10-15 minutes. In the meantime, cook your bacon. I used 3 slices of Hormel Black Label thick sliced bacon (any kind will do). I microwaved it on high for 4  minutes. Yes people, I microwaved the bacon, lol. I poured what little drippings that came off of the bacon into the pot after crumpling the bacon and adding it as well. I did not have any kale or fresh spinach on hand so I substituted a fourth of a head of cabbage, approx. 2 cups. I thinly sliced the cabbage and added it and 1 cup of half and half milk (I used half and half instead of heavy whipping cream, I was fresh out). I let that simmer for about another 10-15 minutes. I also used garlic pepper seasoning to taste

Display Name:
Joanna Lu

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3474852.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup was very easy and good except for one thing: it was incredibly salty. I used bouillon cubes instead of stock. I saved the soup by adding more water until it tasted just slightly too salty, but now I know I will be adding just 2-3 cubes of bouillon for this entire dish versus 5. For anyone using stock, I would recommend half stock and half water, or low sodium stock.

However, once I fixed the salt issue, this soup was delicious! I love that it uses ingredients I generally have anyway, and that it's a one pot dish! As someone with a small kitchen, decreasing the amount of dishes is a must. It was also easy to monitor because of that, and I am generally on calls or multitasking while making dinner. My only other adjustment was using lactose free nonfat milk instead of cream as I am borderline lactose intolerant.
Review:

5

userID:
17848174
Display Name:
David Fields
isPro:
False
followersCount:
6
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
7
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3460073.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family loves this recipe.  We like it spicy so we go ahead and use spicy sausage.  Good, thick sliced bacon is really important or else it just gets lost, applewood bacon adds a lovely flavor, too!  We use kale rather than spinach for the flavor and break it apart into rather small pieces, make sure not to let any stems in.  6 potatoes is fine as far as chunks are concerned, but we like to mince another potato or two and let it cream into the broth, it gives the broth a lot of texture.  Either way, make sure the potatoes are starting to break down before moving on to the cream.  And SOME people need to learn how to account for salt rather than blaming the recipe.  This recipe already has bacon, so keep that in mind when choosing your broth.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-04-04T16:31:11.297
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
14579881

text:
Loved this recipe! I made a few minor changes (which is why I rated 4 not 5). Because so many reviews said how much this soup made, I ended up only using half of what it called for the veggies and meat but using 5-5.5 cups of broth and 3/4 whipping cream. I also used kale instead of spinach And I only had kielbasa so I ended up using that instead of ground sausage. It turned out amazing, definitely keeping this recipe!

text:
This soup is amazing and tasty with just the right amount of kick! I made a few minor adjustments.  I used kale instead of spinach.  I also added in an extra 1/4 cup
Of heavy cream (I didn't want to waste the little bit left in the container).  I also added an extra two slices of bacon and two sweet Italian sausages along with the hot ones, which I used instead of mild. You would think this would make the soup too spicy...it did not. My husband us not a big soup drinker but I couldn't keep him away from this soup! So excellent! I'm about to make more! My husband is picky so I'm thrilled!

text:
This soup is great!  The only changes I made were to use low-sodium broth, and kale instead of spinach.  I only needed 3 servings, so I cut the recipe in half.  If you're doing the same, consider using only 2 potatoes (or 3 smaller potatoes) as the soup thickened up considerably once it cooled.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup is incredibly easy, fast and delicious. The only way to mess it up is to add too much water!! I used water and chicken bouillion instead of broth. To avoid it being too watery, add water as you go. I only used 6 cups of water (the recipe calls for 8) and it was a bit watery for my taste but I just boiled it down. 
I tweaked the recipe a bit. I used 5 chicken bouillon cubes with 6 cups of water and instead of italian sausage I used Italian-seasoned Jenny-O ground turkey from the supermarket. I fried up the turkey and then baked it at 300 degrees  for 20 minutes to crumble it. I also added kale instead of spinach. Since I omitted the sausage, it wasn't as salty as I like so I included salt as well.

text:
Delicious family favorite! Some things I did differently: I used johnsonville hot Italian sausage (I cut the casing off and crumbled it while it cooked). I rinsed the sausage with hot water and blotted dry. I only used two (very large) russet potatoes, substituted the spinach for kale, and added a dash of black pepper and 1 1/2 teaspoon of fennel seed in addition to the listed ingredients. Served with cheesy garlic bread. Definitely a bit spicey, but my seven year old loved it regardless!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
We used spicy sausage and added fennel seeds, substituted kale in place of spinach, and omitted the bacon. Even our pickiest eater ate it! TIP: Take meat out of the pan and place directly into a fine strainer over a bowl. Over time, the residual heat will help all the orange oil drip down into the bowl. You'll still get all the flavor, but you'll avoid the orange oil floating at the top of your soup. If you use kale, boil it for a few minutes before adding the cream. It's tough, and it needs some time to soften a bit.

text:
Great recipe. I've made this soup many times in the last few years. As others have said, kale is key. Also, adding a little fennel seed really does add something that was missing from the original recipe. Also, i suggest not rinsing or blotting the sausage fat. Instead i recommend skimming . takes a bit more time and patience, but you'll get more of that great sausage flavor in the end product.

None
text:
Very delicious!  The only changes I made were to add good quality real bacon bits at the end with half a cup of sour cream and half a cup of heavy cream.  I find the bacon is not limp and soggy like it is if you cook the bacon in the Dutch oven at the beginning.  For a bit lighter, but just as tasty version, use one cup of half and half cream instead of heavy cream.

text:
Absolutely delicious soup. The only change I think I'll do for next time is omit the bacon; this soup totally doesn't need it- there's already so much flavour going on. Also, if you don't watch the video you may be confused about the quantity of broth. It is a total of 8 1/4 c. which may explain why some felt their soup was too salty, perhaps they didn't dilute it enough. Awesome soup and good with turkey sausage if you want a lighter version.

I have made this for years now because my friend worked at this restrant and gave me some clues of how they made it. Only use Italian sausage. No basil blend or stuff like that. Use kale not spinach. I use some heavy cream and some 1/2&1/2. I add 2% milk if needed. I also use three cans chicken broth and two cans vegetable broth. I go with the low sodium broth. Great soup I must say.

text:
I've never had the one from the restaurant, but this was excellent! I didn't need a lot so I halved the recipe, using two artisan sweet Italian chicken sausages that I sliced and sauteed in olive oil. Removed them and then sauteed the onions and garlic. I used one good-sized potato sliced thinly, and it was done in 10 minutes. Used milk in place of the heavy cream and added a little red pepper flakes for heat. I subbed kale for the spinach. It's good to have a bag of chopped frozen kale on hand for this purpose. You just microwave what you need; convenient and no waste. I topped the soup with some grated parmesan and chopped bacon. Thanks for the great recipe that I'm sure to make again!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup is delicious. Perfect for cold winter nights. I, like other reviewers, used kale instead of spinach and I left out the crushed red pepper because I used hot italian sausage. I also used less potato. I used the little fingerling potatoes, maybe 1 LB and sliced them thin. I didn't make any other changes...I just doubled the recipe because we really can't get enough of it. For those who review it as bland, if you want to try it again, try it with hot sausage. All the flavor comes from that! It is so easy and yummy, it will now be a wintertime staple in my house.

text:
1 29 15 ... http://allrecipes.com/recipe/143069/super-delicious-zuppa-toscana/ ... Halved the recipe, subbed 4c beef broth with 2c water (Hey, I was short.  ;D) Instead of fresh, I added 8oz frozen chopped spinach.  That's more than the recipe states, I would think.  Before the cream, it tasted a little too sausage-y.  After the cream, mellowed nicely.  If I make again, I'll add less meat anyway - so I can make three sausage dishes from one pound instead of two.  (I also made this ... http://allrecipes.com/recipe/penne-with-spicy-vodka-tomato-cream-sauce/detail.aspx ... which I rated five stars.  :) ... In New Orleans,good italian restaurant is Irene's.

text:
So. Good. We've tried a few Zuppa Toscana recipes before, but nothing ever tasted good enough to warrant making again. This recipe has become a new favorite. The only things I alter are the amount of potatoes, (recipe calls for 6 but we use 8 or 9 small gold potatoes, sliced very thin) and I use kale instead of spinach. If you like really spicy soup, hot italian sausage gives it more kick. It's also amazing reheated. We serve it with sour dough bread & salad.

text:
After reading reviews, I changed up the recipe. I took the advice of other reviews and added fennel and kale. I diced the potatoes and  boiled them in the broth ect. for 35mins. I used my immersion blender to purée the potatoes to make a thick soup. I added the sausage and kale and simmered the soup for an hour. I was happy with the results, a nice thick and hearty soup.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Turned out really good! I also tweaked the recipe a bit. I browned the italian sausage with the red pepper flakes, then added the chopped onion and minced garlic. Next I removed the sausage and onion mixture and then browned six pieces of bacon in the same skillet that I browned the sausage in. I drained bacon on paper towel and then crumbled. I added crumbled bacon with about 56 oz chicken broth ( I used about 1 and 3/4 of 32 oz chicken broth cartons). Brought to a boil then added 3 large thinly sliced russet potatoes. Took about 15 minutes until potatoes were tender. Then added baby kale instead of spinach. Once kale was wilted, I stirred in sausage mixture and about 1 cup cream. Tasted and added a few pinches of salt, and more crushed red pepper. Soup was tasty but still missing something. Added about 2 tablespoons of butter to soup which added the "rich" flavor that I felt was missing. Tasted perfect. Only missing breadsticks!

text:
In my opinion, this soup taste exactly like what's served at Olive Garden; in my boyfriend's opinion, it's better. Either way, great. I used gold potatoes instead of russets, which held their form better. Added 1 tsp each of sweet basil and fennel and used more bacon (maybe 6 or 7 slices), as well as 1 1/2 c of heavy cream. I also used a few extra tsp of chicken bouillon, and still thought it needed salt and pepper, but that was an easy fix to a great meal.

text:
Absolutely delicious! This is my fiancée's favorite soup from the O.G & he loves that it tastes JUST like it. I did feel like 6 potatoes would be too much so I used 4 instead, cut them thicker, & did not cook them all the way in the chicken broth but instead let them finish cooking during the heating process of the heavy whipping cream and sausage so that they wouldn't crumble at the end. I used Kale (instead of spinach) and also added it at the time of heating everything through.

This is a truly delicious soup just the way it is written!  I wanted to make it even more hearty and filling for a very cold November night here in Georgia (Polar Vortex)!! text:
Very Simple, EXTREMELY tasty....... I tried Zuppa Toscana on a whim at Olive Garden many moons ago and fell in love with it. It's very flavorful and filling....be careful to drain the fat from the sausage or it will give the heavy cream a redish/pink tinge when done....." molto Bella"   


I did use KALE and I added it between the Cream and Sausage steps. Kale is not as tender as spinach so I cooked it longer about 5 minutes on medium heat.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup was just what I was hoping it would be. A good quality chicken broth (or homemade) is the key ingredient. I used mild Italian turkey sausage because it's leaner than pork and cooked it together with the onion, garlic, and red pepper flakes to bring out the flavors.  Substituted kale for spinach and half & half for cream.  If making this soup for the first time you may wish to reduce the red pepper flakes - you can always add more at the end if it's not spicy enough.  Next time I'll add some carrot strips at the end for a little color.

text:
Great Recipe! I made this a little healthier by subbing the bacon and sausage with turkey bacon and turkey italian sausage. I also did half organic veggie broth and half organic chicken broth. For heavy cream I combined 1 cup of milk with 2 tablespoons of corn starch and 1 tablespoon of unbleached flour, Whip then all together vigorously then add to the soup and simmer and stir until thickened. Also used baby kale instead of spinach. Great flavor! My partner and I loved it.

None
text:
I made a pork-free, gluten-free, reduced-dairy version of this and it turned out great! Substituting gluten-free chicken sausage (I used Al Fresco brand) and adding a little water with the red pepper worked well. In place of the heavy cream I mixed 1/2 cup of all-purpose gluten-free flour with 1/2 cup of 2% milk. I know this doesn't sound nearly as appetizing, but I can confidently say that it tasted just as good as Olive Garden's Zuppa!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This has become one of my favorites. Not only is it absolutely delicious, but it's super simple to make and calls for inexpensive ingredients. My sister and I get together regularly to try new recipes and we're so disappointed when the dish doesn't look like it should ( or taste, for that matter :p) Needless to say, we're foodies so we needed to try to cut down on a bit of the decadence but still keep it flavorful. We used spicy Italian sausage instead of mild and omitted the chili flakes. We also decided to leave out the bacon, we used half and half instead of heavy cream and substituted kale for the spinach. Despite the changes, it was still rich and flavorful, definitely a keeper. Thanks soupersweets!!

text:
This soup is nothing short of AMAZING!!!!!! I've made this twice so far and the second time was for a group of about 20 to 25 people. Even the children were coming back for seconds and thirds!! EVERYONE raved about it! I took the advice of some of the other reviewers and rinsed the sausage in really hot water to keep it from being orange and to get rid of some of the grease. I also used kale (a lot of it) since that's what the famous restaurant uses and no one complained, not even my husband and kids who dislike kale. Other than that, I followed the recipe as written. I tripled the recipe to feed the group and everyone had plenty and we had some to take home!!! Thank you so much for sharing this reccipe :)

Love this soup!  I used lactose free whole milk in place of cream and added a touch of corn starch to thicken. The potatoes could do that on their own, but I like them to keep their shape, so I don't overlook.  I did add a touch of garlic salt at serving because I used mild sausage and no pepper flakes. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW! This was amazing. I love soup and I figured with 5 stars it had to be great. I read reviews and made the following adjustments, it really was exceptional! Family and guests loved it!
Used low-sodium chicken broth (I can see it would have been way too salty if I hadn't)
Used hot sausage, left out the pepper flakes.
Used kale instead of spinach (added just about 10 minutes before serving).
Cooked 1/2 pound of bacon and reserved some for sprinkling on top in bowl.
Added some black pepper and thyme to taste.
Sliced 2 potatoes very thin, 4 thicker - making all pieces bit sized.
Served with shredded cheddar for top of bowl.

userID:
4310897
Display Name:
Trish-the-Dish
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5

0
madeRecipesCount:
518
favoritesCount:
1250
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I always order the Zuppa Toscana at the popular Italian restaurant.  So, I was happy to find this recipe.  It tasted better than the restaurant version because I added my own personal touches.  Used kale instead of spinach, cooking for 5 min. after adding it...otherwise the kale would be too tough.  Added more red pepper flakes, simply because we like things spicy!  Didn't have heavy cream so I used 2% milk and added a few tablespoons of butter.  Because I only had turkey bacon on hand, and used it, the flavor was lacking.  Don't cringe, but to get the bacon flavor, I added a tablespoon of reserved, strained bacon grease I had in the refrigerator.  Like my mother and grandmother, I always save strained bacon grease for certain cooking strategies.  One last thing, I didn't have "sausage" but I had ground pork...to make up for the lack of spices normally found in sausage, I needed to add spices.  So a few shakes of garlic powder, onion powder, oregano, sweet basil, black pepper, and salt were added.  I probably could not duplicate the ingredients exactly if I tried, but it made a wonderful Zuppa!  I share these ideas to encourage others to make it their own.  A soup we truly enjoyed!

I substituted chopped fresh kale for the spinach and added it with the potatoes. Put about 4 packed cups in but think I'll up it to 6 next time. Cut the potatoes 1/8" thick with my mandolin. Very good and the red pepper gave it a nice kick. Midwestern husband loved it- and he's not a fan of Italian sausage.

I also removed 2 quarts for freezing after adding the sausage but before the cream. Cream soups don't freeze well. So with the cup of cream mine was a little richer than the recipe called for. Awesome!

text:
This is one fantastic soup! I just had my second bowl. I wouldn't change a thing with regard to the ingredients used. However, the recipe was vague about the size of the potatoes, whether they should be peeled or not and how big of a bunch of spinach to use. I used about 5 ounces of spinach, and 9 smallish Idaho red potatoes. Next time, I'll peel the potatoes to avoid having strips of peel and will trim away all of the spinach stems. I'll be making this again soon.

text:
THis soup is outstanding, hearty and oh so good on a cold winter night- a classic Italian peasant soup.  After reading a bunch of reviews, I adapted the recipe, many thanks for the tips!  I used mild Italian poultry sausage patties, instead of pork, and kale instead of spinach. I chunked my potatoes instead of slicing them.  I omitted the milk/heavy cream because I forgot(in the end its excellent without it)!  With the potatoes in the soup for thickener.  I served it with a side salad, and hearty 9 grain bread.  With this Polar Vortex swirling through upstate NY for the third time this winter, this soup is perfect to warm you up and fill your tummy with amazing comfort food!!  Thank you!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making my own "knock-off" recipe for awhile.  I only put in 1/2 tsp. of cayenne, and that gives it enough kick for us.  It depends upon the size of potatoes you use, but I use 3 medium russets, unpeeled.  I slice the slices in half.  Instead of the fresh spinach, I thaw a frozen box of chopped spinach, wring it dry, and add it at the end.  I know the restaurant chain uses kale, but our preference is the spinach.  Also, instead of 5 cans of chicken broth, I use two; one quart of water and 3 tsps. of granulated chicken base. Great recipe!

text:
Absolutely delicious!  While I've never tried Olive Garden's Zuppa Toscana, this recipe spoke to me, and I had everything on hand.  It smelled so good while cooking.  My picky 12-year-old daughter LOVED it!  She cleaned her bowl (and even ate the kale).  I used kale in place of the spinach as a recommendation from other reviewers.  I didn't have any cream on hand, so I used a cup of milk and three TBSP. of cornstarch (a recommendation from another reviewer).  Make sure you dissolve the cornstarch in water before adding it to the soup.  I also used golden potatoes, and instead of adding red pepper flakes, I added cayenne pepper. This is a definite keeper.

userID:
11276266
Display Name:
kokopelli
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have tried the soup and its a good recipe, I do mine a little different and have good reviews when I serve it, small children can enjoy it also as I don't use red pepper flakes.Instead of ground sausage I use Johnsonville mild Italian sausage links, Olive Garden uses this also, for the two of us I use three links. With a point of a sharp knife I poke about three holes in each link. Put them in a Dutch Oven with about an inch of water. Bring to a boil and reduce heat. Cover and let simmer until water is gone and sausages are done. Remove. Let cool and slice on the diagonal about 1/4 to 1/2 inch wide.Cook bacon, onion and garlic in same pan with a little oil until crispy and remove and drain on paper towel. Peel and cut potatoes, I use about 2 large for the two of us, into quarters. Bring water and potatoes to a boil, cook until done and add prior ingredients. Add broth or water with bouillion and cook until hot. Add 3 to 4 Cups Kale and cream. Simmer about 4 minutes and serve with croutons on top. 
Sausages may be cooked in the oven on a cookie sheet at 300 degrees until done, drain, cool and slice.

text:
This was good, but not the best ever, so I withheld a star.  I think I added too much broth for I didn't read that it called for the smaller cans of broth and not the 15 ounce ones.  I think cannellini beans would have tasted good in it.  I didn't bother with all the separate sautéing steps, rather I just sautéed the sausage for about 5 minutes, then added the onions for 5 minutes, and lastly the bacon, before dumping it all the rest of the ingredients on top.  This worked well for ease and for flavor; the only thing that didn't go so well is that the bacon didn't get crisp this way.  I also didn't totally boil it as the recipe states.  Instead I simmered on low with the lid on.

text:
Wow!  Even better the second day!!  I followed the recipe fairly closely, though left out the crushed red pepper flakes as my family doesn't do spicy.  I upped the garlic to 4 cloves.  I used a whole 32 oz. box of chicken broth and then realized I had an open one in the fridge (not sure how much was in there - maybe a cup?) so I threw that in as well.  I used 3 very large russet potatoes, sliced - and left the skins on as I'd read in another site's recipe.  Not sure if I'll do that again, but it did add some flavor and texture.  Again, following other recipes, I substituted kale for the spinach, and loved it - it doesn't mush down completely like spinach would - and I think it's the first time 2 of my family members have ever eaten kale voluntarily!  I did use the heavy cream, but wonder if some of the other substitutions to cut down on fat would work well - may try next time.  This soup was amazing!  I had some for breakfast this morning..... why wait?!?  UPDATE: 10/11/14 - made tonight with half beef broth/half chicken broth - just because I had both to use up.  Every bit as good!

This was very good but next time I'll tweek it a little. I don't like a lot of broth, so I'll use only 3 cans next time instead of 5. I'll also leave out the bacon because I saw no need for it. I tried Low-sodium broth because of a few reviews, but next time I'll use regular...for more flavor. I couldn't find the spicy ground Italian sausage like one reviewer suggested, but next time I'll look harder because the red pepper flakes didn't make it spicy at all. I used milk instead of heavy cream & of course kale instead of spinach like EVERYONE recommended & I thoroughly enjoyed it. city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe for a long long time. I usually go to another web site to find the recipe. I just recently found it here. Its a dead ringer to the Olive Garden that serves it. 

In fact, my wife says its even better. I dont use a dutch oven. I just use a very large pan. I dont use cans of broth. I use Chicken Bullion cubes.

I dont use either spinach or kale. But kale does add a bit of color, which is nice. I use the food processor to cut up my onions for me. Just be careful not to leave them in too long or you will wind up with onion soup. I use lots of potatoes. But use however many you like. 

Depends if you like your soup more patotoeeee. I also put my bacon in a food processor to make it bacon bitee.

country:
None
text:
YUMMMMM! This soup is so delicious I never have any leftovers, even though there are only two of us in the household. Although we loved the soup, my husband complained it was too "runny". To make a thicker cream soup I made a roux (1/4c butter to 1/4 flour over medium heat and cook until peanut butter-colored) and I wisked that in right after the potatos finished cooking, before adding in the cream. I also use frozen spinach (I usually always have it on hand in my home) and I just add it in frozen. It thaws out so quickly...no need to waste time pre-cooking. This is a family favorite...thanks so much for sharing!!

Display Name:
vstruck

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3146041.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is absolutely amazing.  I heated some up for lunch today at work and got compliments on the delicious smell.  This will definitely be a staple in my recipe box, it is so good.  The softness of the potatoes mixed with the saltiness of the bacon and sausage is so satisfying.  The broth is really savory and the soup eats like a meal.  I made two changes.  I included fennel seed, which MAKES the flavor of this soup.  I can't imagine it without fennel.  Also, I substituted kale for spinach.  The kale softens in the soup but does not become mushy.  I added the kale at the same time that I added the potatoes.  I used pre-cooked, pre-crumbled pork sausage which was a big time saver. I didn't add red pepper flakes, and I didn't miss them.  This is a perfect recipe!

text:
Great flavor.  I made half the amount.  I used ground pork instead of sausage so we used a bit of pepper and spice to give it the flavor needed.  My husband though it was fairly plain until I added the cream, which improved the soup.  Everyone liked it, eating it with no complaints :) My son requested that I make it again.  As suggested by others, I used more potatoes and left them in big chunks.  Potatoes cooked in about 15 minutes.  I reduced the pepper flakes to a small pinch, figuring the spiciness can be adjusted individually. We ate this with butter crackers.

text:
Not that another review is needed, but since I've never had the restaurant soup, this was pretty good! We had it two nights ago and just finished leftovers for dinner this evening. I used Johnsonville's 1/2 pork and chicken sausage to save a few calories and omitted the red pepper flakes to make it kid-friendly (DH sprinkled some into his bowl). I formed the sausage into dime-sized balls and browned them along with the chopped onion. I used spinach simply because I didn't have kale on hand, and tossed in some sundried tomatoes I wanted to use up. I subbed half and half for the heavy cream, but would prefer it next time with the heavy cream. I am a garlic fiend and tossed a few cloves I roasted earlier in the evening.  Also added a sprinkling of black pepper as it simmered.  Topped our bowls with parmesan and ate with side of garlic bread. Definitely a repeat for us!

I loved this recipe! While I tweaked it to my family's taste, it is fantastic without alteration. In order to make the broth thicker and creamier, I used 4 potatoes and 2 cups of potato flakes. Since it was thicker and creamier, I cut down the cream to 3/4 of a cup. We also like some heat so I used hot sausage links sliced thinly. I did not have fresh spinach available, so I used a 1/2 package of frozen chopped spinach.

This turned out really well.  I even made it in a crockpot.  I browned the sausages in an oven first, but then everything went into the crockpot till just before serving.  At that point I added kale for the spinach and half & half for the heavy cream.  I even cheated a bit and wanted the consistancy to be slightly thicker... so I added a bit of instant mash potatoes to thicken the soup just a tad.

This recipe was AMAZING! I forgot to use bacon, but it was still delishous, I also used more cream then called for 1 cup I used 2 cups instead instead. Just because I wanted a bit more liquid and a more creamy taste. As the other reviews stated Kale is the better choice it stays crisp. My family raved about it and my dad said it was better then the soup at that popular restaurant. My sister wants the recipe to make for her friends. This is a very easy recipe, oh and on a side note I don't have a dutch oven I just used a regular big pot and I cooked the the other ingrediants in a pan. Still came out Amazing :) Try it!

Very good. I did do a lower fat version, used turkey sausage and turkey bacon. If you go this route, I would suggest using a little EVOO when adding the onion since you aren't going to get the fat drippings like you do when using pork bacon. Used low sodium chx broth and added salt to taste at the end. used kale, also added kale and sausage when adding the low fat milk. tasted great.

text:
This was pretty good and even better on day 2. The Italian Sausage Soup on this site is much easier and is more delicious, though. I made it as written except I only added 3 large potatoes. More would have been too many. I had to add quite a bit of salt at the end to keep the broth from being too bland. I also used half and half instead of heavy cream.

text:
This is my family's new FAVORITE soup.  I have made this many times over the last few months. I almost always tweak recipes,but this one is perfect for me as is. I will try using Kale eventually, but I almost always have spinach around so that's what I use.  I don't add the bacon in the pot, but crumble it into the bowls when I serve...that way, there is a nice crunch to the soup. Update: tried it w/ Kale and it is very good.  I had extra, so I made Kale Chips as a snack while the soup simmered!  :)

text:
So impressed!!  I used the kale instead of spinach, diced the potatoes in @ 1/2 inch cubes, forgot and used Jimmy Dean pork sausage instead of italian (just added some italian spices).  First time ever using kale...it was perfect in this, as the spinach would have been a bit slimy after it cooked, but the kale was great.  This soup is wonderful to make the day before a dinner party...maybe even better the second day as there was no change in consistancy after heating again.  Small kids might think it a bit spicy...but we think it is superb!!

text:
This is my favorite soup!  I have referred this to many people and everyone loves it.  I do use spinach instead.  I use low sodium chicken broth and to the viewer that didn't like because it was too salty.  It could have been the sausage she used and chicken bouillon if used is extremely high in sodium.  Makes a huge difference!  I use Trader Joes low sodium Chicken Broth in the box.  Scimecas italian sausage too, which is delicious! Sometimes I add a little more potatoes and broth, but that's just a preference I choose sometimes, don't have to.  LOVE IT!

text:
Absolutely delicious!! Pretty quick preparation.   Changes to make it healthier: I used chicken italian sausage (which was so hot I definitely did NOT use pepper flakes), light cream, and turkey bacon.  I also followed other rater's advice and added fennel, only used 4 potatoes and substituted kale for spinach.  I will definitely make again and absolutely LOVE it. Rave reviews!

text:
This soup is definitely irresistable. I tried it for the first time a couple of years ago at Olive Garden and was hooked. I prefer to use spicy Italian sausage, a lot of kale, and alot of chili flakes. This recipe also doesn't specify but I love to keep the skin on the potato because it holds the potato slices better. I also use a water and chicken bouillon mix if I don't have chicken broth available. Haven't tried it with spinach but I'm sure it's also good, just not amazing like kale is.

text:
This soup was absolutely delicious! I will definitely use this recipe again. I am giving it 4 stars instead of 5 because cooking the red pepper flakes in the beginning created a toxic fume in my kitchen! text:
I couldn't believe was able to make something that tasted that good so easily! I would highly encourage readers to try this out. I used half and half instead of heavy cream and thickened the soup up with around tablespoon of cornstarch. I also like almost all other reviewers used kale instead of spinach. You can adjust the spiciness to your liking with the red peppers and add other ingredients such as mushrooms, zucchini or other veggies. Enjoy!!!

Yummy! I used hot Italian sausage, omitted bacon and red pepper flakes and 1 can of fat free evaporated milk for the cream. I use Herboxo salt free chicken bouillon for the chicken stock. userID:
4139387
Display Name:
Robbin Dye Moore
isPro:

2

7
favoritesCount:
92
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7531029.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
this is delicious, my husband called it the best soup he has ever had and said he hoped there was enough for leftovers tonight!  I browned the bacon a little first, then added the sausage with the pepper flakes, onion, and garlic and cooked it till well browned, drained that and then added my sliced potatoes and stirred them around with the meat for about 10 minutes just to let them pick up the flavors of the meat, then i stirred in the broth and cooked till the potatoes were soft and then added my cream.  Not everyone at my house will eat spinach so we just put a handful of spinach in our bowls and ladled the hot soup over it.  This is a classic "comfort soup" and will definitly be a go to recipe at our house.

Instead of the 4 slices of bacon I used a couple tablespoons of the pre cooked bacon pieces and threw them into the sausage when it was nearly browned. Got the flavor without the fat. And instead of the cream I used a can of low fat evaporated milk mixed with a couple tablespoons of cornstarch. That gives you a little more feel of the cream without the fat also.  And I used kale instead of spinach. Loved it! and so did hubby. I'll be begged to make this again and again.

country:
None
text:
Turned out really good for the first cool New England day of the year.  I used turkey sausage, browned it with bit of EVOO, onion, green pepper, celery, garlic and red pepper flakes.  Added the chicken stock, 6 cubed red potatoes with the skin on and a whole bunch of chopped kale (no stems).  Brought to a boil and then added the bacon and simmered for an hour.  Finished it off with a cup of light cream.  Served it with the roasted garlic bread on this site.  Hubby thought it was fantabulous!

text:
I thought this tasted exactly like the OG version, which I like, so I really liked this. I did use kale instead of spinach, milk with cornstarch instead of cream, and hot instead of mild sausage. I kept a sprinkle of red pepper flakes and didn't find the result too hot. In fact, next time I'll add more red pepper. I also tossed in some fennel per another review.   My only complaint is that I found this too thick. I'm not sure what other people did to make it too thin, but next time I'll add a little extra broth or something to thin it out. Regardless, I give it 5 stars for tasting like what I expected. The things I'd like to fix will be easy enough to fix next time. Thanks!

text:
FANTASTIC recipe! Everyone loved it and had seconds- including my son and nephews! I substituted kale for spinach as others suggested- my husband asked why the "spinach tasted so good" in it- the kale really retained a nice fresh flavor and crispness. I substituted some cut up proscuitto ham both times I made it- didn't have any bacon. It add some nice flavor and texture- I could really take it or leave it though- the soup stand fine on its own without it. The first time I made it, I used ruby gold potatoes, the second time I used russet- both cooked just fine. My husband took leftovers to work and said at least 3 co-workers asked him to have me pass on the recipe! I told him to have them check it out on this site!

text:
I made this for dinner tonight for our family of 5.  It's all gone and I made a large batch!  The only thing I changed was that I had a leek on hand so I threw it in and I used Half and Half.  Don't cut back on the potatoes, unless you have the huge baking potatoes.  It thickens the soup for you.  Next time I make (which I definitely will!) I will make it with a low sodium bacon and maybe turkey Italian sausage.  I found the bacon and sausage I used made it a bit salty for me.  Otherwise, EXCELLENT recipe!  Thanks for posting it!

text:
I love this soup... I used fat free half and half and only 1 large potato, as I prefer a more brothy soup than chunky... i also used Kale... Delicious!  On a side note... I've tried to cut corners and leave the sausage in the pan the whole time, rather than setting it aside and draining it... it still tastes good, but there is an orange grease layer on top of the soup if you do this... doesn't really alter the taste, but it looks a lot better if you drain the sausage (not to mention the extra fat is removed)

text:
I made this delicious soup last night on the coldest night we have had in Texas and now it is darling hubby's (dh) favorite!  I buy organic whenever possible so I made healthy changes to this recipe by substituting: 4 All-natural link Italian Sausages sliced into bite sized pieces (to please dh); One 32 oz.carton Free range chicken broth; organic spinach and I also added sea salt. I also used 5 red potatoes with skins, thinly sliced, they cook faster than the white.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Based on what I had on hand I modified this recipe a bit, but it still turned out terrific!
I used hot italian turkey sausage cooked with casings removed and 1tsp of red pepper, and omitted the bacon (didn't have any).  I also replaced the potato with a head of cauliflower.  I only had one can of chicken broth, so for the remainder I used water and chicken base. 
It was delicious!  
My husband loved it as is, but thought the bacon would make it even better, so I'll definately try that next time.  
This is a wonderful cold weather soup that will be in our regular rotation!
Review:

This is a meal.  I doubled the recipe using 1 large can of chicken broth, a whole bulb of garlic, 1 large bag of spinach, and a cup of water. It just doesn't need it and it's one extra step I don't have time for.

text:
this is my new favorite zuppa toscana recipe.  I don't have a dutch oven, so I removed the casing off of 16 oz of italian sausage and baked them for 25 minutes at 350 degrees and then cut lengthwise and sliced diagonally.  In a large pot I sauteed onions and garlic in 1/4 t crushed red pepper and added the chopped bacon when the onions were tender.  Next I added the rest of the ingredients as listed in the recipe; however, I used 2 cups of shredded kale instead of spinach.

Great soup!  I didn't have any spinach so I left that out.  That was the only thing I changed.  It is not supposed to be a thick soup, it is a thin soup, so do not worry about adding corn starch or anything to thicken it.  

I used red potatoes and left the skin on so that seemed to help hold my thin potato slices together while they cooked.

Awesome soup!  I am glad I didn't cut down on the potatoes like some reviews said because I think that is what gives the broth a thicker texture.  Next time I might even add an extra potato.  When I bought the sausage my market only had it in 1 1/2 lbs and I ended up using all of it because I was so hungry and it wasn't too much for the soup to handle.  I can't wait to eat the leftovers!

Display Name:
catholic soup queen

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/121.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I liked this recipe as I read it and liked it even more when I made it. I skipped the potatoes since they aren't in our low carb meal plan (but I did add 2 sm stalks of chopped celery). Once the sausage, bacon, onions and garlic were sauted, I tossed them into the crock-pot. I deglazed the pan with my homemade chicken broth to get some of the flavors into the soup, then added to the crock as well. I waited until 15 to 20 minutes before serving to add the spinach and cream. I thicken with a bit of guar gum. Since the meat was cooked, I set crock-pot on low for 3.5 hours. Served with a crustless broccoli quiche and a homemade low-carb chocolate cake in celebration of the Pope's arrival and His Birthday today. Very good! Could have sprinkled with some Parmesano Reggiano...will do it tomorrow with my leftovers and it will reach 5 stars immediately.

text:
This soup is a winner.  I will make it for my next gathering for sure!  I used 6 slices of the thick cut applewood bacon.  I used a pint of heavy whipping cream, and I used the spicy italian sausage instead of the mild and just tailored the red pepper to taste since my family likes a spicier soup.  Also I used Tones chicken base instead of the broth (it has a more full bodied robust flavor than plain broth).  I added some cornstarch to thicken.  Needless to say last nights dinner was a hit and guess what I am sitting here eating for breakfast :)
